HED.prologue:
This schema is a Hierarchical Event Descriptors (HED) Library Schema implementation of Standardized Computer-based Organized Reporting of EEG (SCORE)[1,2] for describing events occurring during neuroimaging time series recordings. The HED-SCORE library schema allows neurologists, neurophysiologists, and brain researchers to annotate electrophysiology recordings using terms from an internationally accepted set of defined terms (SCORE) compatible with the HED framework. The resulting annotations are understandable to clinicians and directly usable in computer analysis.
Future extensions may be implemented in the HED-SCORE library schema. For more information see https://hed-schema-library.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html.

node.name: Event
node.description: Something that happens at a given time and (typically) place. Elements of this tag subtree designate the general category in which an event falls.

node.name: Sensory-event
node.description: Something perceivable by the participant. An event meant to be an experimental stimulus should include the tag Task-property/Task-event-role/Experimental-stimulus.

node.name: Agent-action
node.description: Any action engaged in by an agent (see the Agent subtree for agent categories). A participant response to an experiment stimulus should include the tag Agent-property/Agent-task-role/Experiment-participant.

node.name: Data-feature
node.description: An event marking the occurrence of a data feature such as an interictal spike or alpha burst that is often added post hoc to the data record.

node.name: Experiment-control
node.description: An event pertaining to the physical control of the experiment during its operation.

node.name: Experiment-procedure
node.description: An event indicating an experimental procedure, as in performing a saliva swab during the experiment or administering a survey.

node.name: Experiment-structure
node.description: An event specifying a change-point of the structure of experiment. This event is typically used to indicate a change in experimental conditions or tasks.

node.name: Measurement-event
node.description: A discrete measure returned by an instrument.

node.name: Agent
node.description: Someone or something that takes an active role or produces a specified effect.The role or effect may be implicit. Being alive or performing an activity such as a computation may qualify something to be an agent. An agent may also be something that simulates something else.

node.name: Animal-agent
node.description: An agent that is an animal.

node.name: Avatar-agent
node.description: An agent associated with an icon or avatar representing another agent.

node.name: Controller-agent
node.description: An agent experiment control software or hardware.

node.name: Human-agent
node.description: A person who takes an active role or produces a specified effect.

node.name: Robotic-agent
node.description: An agent mechanical device capable of performing a variety of often complex tasks on command or by being programmed in advance.

node.name: Software-agent
node.description: An agent computer program.

node.name: Modulator
node.description: External stimuli / interventions or changes in the alertness level (sleep) that modify: the background activity, or how often a graphoelement is occurring, or change other features of the graphoelement (like intra-burst frequency). For each observed finding, there is an option of specifying how they are influenced by the modulators and procedures that were done during the recording.
Free text.

node.name: Background-activity
node.description: An EEG activity representing the setting in which a given normal or abnormal pattern appears and from which such pattern is distinguished.

node.name: Posterior-dominant-rhythm
node.description: Rhythmic activity occurring during wakefulness over the posterior regions of the head, generally with maximum amplitudes over the occipital areas. Amplitude varies. Best seen with eyes closed and during physical relaxation and relative mental inactivity. Blocked or attenuated by attention, especially visual, and mental effort. In adults this is the alpha rhythm, and the frequency is 8 to 13 Hz. However the frequency can be higher or lower than this range (often a supra or sub harmonic of alpha frequency) and is called alpha variant rhythm (fast and slow alpha variant rhythm). In children, the normal range of the frequency of the posterior dominant rhythm is age-dependant.

node.name: Mu-rhythm
node.description: EEG rhythm at 7-11 Hz composed of arch-shaped waves occurring over the central or centro-parietal regions of the scalp during wakefulness. Amplitudes varies but is mostly below 50 microV. Blocked or attenuated most clearly by contralateral movement, thought of movement, readiness to move or tactile stimulation.

node.name: Other-organized-rhythm
node.description: EEG activity that consisting of waves of approximately constant period, which is considered as part of the background (ongoing) activity, but does not fulfill the criteria of the posterior dominant rhythm.
Free text.

node.name: Background-activity-special-feature
node.description: Special Features. Special features contains scoring options for the background activity of critically ill patients.

node.name: Background-burst-suppression
node.description: EEG pattern consisting of bursts (activity appearing and disappearing abruptly) interrupted by periods of low amplitude (below 20 microV) and which occurs simultaneously over all head regions.

node.name: Background-activity-suppression
node.description: Periods showing activity under 10 microV (referential montage) and interrupting the background (ongoing) activity.

node.name: Electrocerebral-inactivity
node.description: Absence of any ongoing cortical electric activities; in all leads EEG is isoelectric or only contains artifacts. Sensitivity has to be increased up to 2 microV/mm; recording time: at least 30 minutes.

node.name: Action
node.description: Do something.

node.name: Communicate
node.description: Convey knowledge of or information about something.

node.name: Communicate-gesturally
node.description: Communicate nonverbally using visible bodily actions, either in place of speech or together and in parallel with spoken words. Gestures include movement of the hands, face, or other parts of the body.

node.name: Clap-hands
node.description: Strike the palms of against one another resoundingly, and usually repeatedly, especially to express approval.

node.name: Clear-throat
node.description: Cough slightly so as to speak more clearly, attract attention, or to express hesitancy before saying something awkward.

node.name: Frown
node.description: Express disapproval, displeasure, or concentration, typically by turning down the corners of the mouth.

node.name: Grimace
node.description: Make a twisted expression, typically expressing disgust, pain, or wry amusement.

node.name: Nod-head
node.description: Tilt head in alternating up and down arcs along the sagittal plane. It is most commonly, but not universally, used to indicate agreement, acceptance, or acknowledgement.

node.name: Pump-fist
node.description: Raise with fist clenched in triumph or affirmation.

node.name: Raise-eyebrows
node.description: Move eyebrows upward.

node.name: Shake-fist
node.description: Clench hand into a fist and shake to demonstrate anger.

node.name: Shake-head
node.description: Turn head from side to side as a way of showing disagreement or refusal.

node.name: Shhh
node.description: Place finger over lips and possibly uttering the syllable shhh to indicate the need to be quiet.

node.name: Shrug
node.description: Lift shoulders up towards head to indicate a lack of knowledge about a particular topic.

node.name: Smile
node.description: Form facial features into a pleased, kind, or amused expression, typically with the corners of the mouth turned up and the front teeth exposed.

node.name: Spread-hands
node.description: Spread hands apart to indicate ignorance.

node.name: Thumb-up
node.description: Extend the thumb upward to indicate approval.

node.name: Thumbs-down
node.description: Extend the thumb downward to indicate disapproval.

node.name: Wave
node.description: Raise hand and move left and right, as a greeting or sign of departure.

node.name: Widen-eyes
node.description: Open eyes and possibly with eyebrows lifted especially to express surprise or fear.

node.name: Wink
node.description: Close and open one eye quickly, typically to indicate that something is a joke or a secret or as a signal of affection or greeting.

node.name: Communicate-musically
node.description: Communicate using music.

node.name: Hum
node.description: Make a low, steady continuous sound like that of a bee. Sing with the lips closed and without uttering speech.

node.name: Play-instrument
node.description: Make musical sounds using an instrument.

node.name: Sing
node.description: Produce musical tones by means of the voice.

node.name: Vocalize
node.description: Utter vocal sounds.

node.name: Whistle
node.description: Produce a shrill clear sound by forcing breath out or air in through the puckered lips.

node.name: Communicate-vocally
node.description: Communicate using mouth or vocal cords.

node.name: Cry
node.description: Shed tears associated with emotions, usually sadness but also joy or frustration.

node.name: Groan
node.description: Make a deep inarticulate sound in response to pain or despair.

node.name: Laugh
node.description: Make the spontaneous sounds and movements of the face and body that are the instinctive expressions of lively amusement and sometimes also of contempt or derision.

node.name: Scream
node.description: Make loud, vociferous cries or yells to express pain, excitement, or fear.

node.name: Shout
node.description: Say something very loudly.

node.name: Sigh
node.description: Emit a long, deep, audible breath expressing sadness, relief, tiredness, or a similar feeling.

node.name: Speak
node.description: Communicate using spoken language.

node.name: Whisper
node.description: Speak very softly using breath without vocal cords.

node.name: Move
node.description: Move in a specified direction or manner. Change position or posture.

node.name: Breathe
node.description: Inhale or exhale during respiration.

node.name: Blow
node.description: Expel air through pursed lips.

node.name: Cough
node.description: Suddenly and audibly expel air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation.

node.name: Exhale
node.description: Blow out or expel breath.

node.name: Hiccup
node.description: Involuntarily spasm the diaphragm and respiratory organs, with a sudden closure of the glottis and a characteristic sound like that of a cough.

node.name: Hold-breath
node.description: Interrupt normal breathing by ceasing to inhale or exhale.

node.name: Inhale
node.description: Draw in with the breath through the nose or mouth.

node.name: Sneeze
node.description: Suddenly and violently expel breath through the nose and mouth.

node.name: Sniff
node.description: Draw in air audibly through the nose to detect a smell, to stop it from running, or to express contempt.

node.name: Move-body
node.description: Move entire body.

node.name: Bend
node.description: Move body in a bowed or curved manner.

node.name: Dance
node.description: Perform a purposefully selected sequences of human movement often with aesthetic or symbolic value. Move rhythmically to music, typically following a set sequence of steps.

node.name: Fall-down
node.description: Lose balance and collapse.

node.name: Flex
node.description: Cause a muscle to stand out by contracting or tensing it. Bend a limb or joint.

node.name: Jerk
node.description: Make a quick, sharp, sudden movement.

node.name: Lie-down
node.description: Move to a horizontal or resting position.

node.name: Recover-balance
node.description: Return to a stable, upright body position.

node.name: Shudder
node.description: Tremble convulsively, sometimes as a result of fear or revulsion.

node.name: Sit-down
node.description: Move from a standing to a sitting position.

node.name: Sit-up
node.description: Move from lying down to a sitting position.

node.name: Stand-up
node.description: Move from a sitting to a standing position.

node.name: Stretch
node.description: Straighten or extend body or a part of body to its full length, typically so as to tighten muscles or in order to reach something.

node.name: Stumble
node.description: Trip or momentarily lose balance and almost fall.

node.name: Turn
node.description: Change or cause to change direction.

node.name: Move-body-part
node.description: Move one part of a body.

node.name: Move-eyes
node.description: Move eyes.

node.name: Blink
node.description: Shut and open the eyes quickly.

node.name: Close-eyes
node.description: Lower and keep eyelids in a closed position.

node.name: Fixate
node.description: Direct eyes to a specific point or target.

node.name: Inhibit-blinks
node.description: Purposely prevent blinking.

node.name: Open-eyes
node.description: Raise eyelids to expose pupil.

node.name: Saccade
node.description: Move eyes rapidly between fixation points.

node.name: Squint
node.description: Squeeze one or both eyes partly closed in an attempt to see more clearly or as a reaction to strong light.

node.name: Stare
node.description: Look fixedly or vacantly at someone or something with eyes wide open.

node.name: Move-face
node.description: Move the face or jaw.

node.name: Bite
node.description: Seize with teeth or jaws an object or organism so as to grip or break the surface covering.

node.name: Burp
node.description: Noisily release air from the stomach through the mouth. Belch.

node.name: Chew
node.description: Repeatedly grinding, tearing, and or crushing with teeth or jaws.

node.name: Gurgle
node.description: Make a hollow bubbling sound like that made by water running out of a bottle.

node.name: Swallow
node.description: Cause or allow something, especially food or drink to pass down the throat.

node.name: Gulp
node.description: Swallow quickly or in large mouthfuls, often audibly, sometimes to indicate apprehension.

node.name: Yawn
node.description: Take a deep involuntary inhalation with the mouth open often as a sign of drowsiness or boredom.

node.name: Move-head
node.description: Move head.

node.name: Lift-head
node.description: Tilt head back lifting chin.

node.name: Lower-head
node.description: Move head downward so that eyes are in a lower position.

node.name: Turn-head
node.description: Rotate head horizontally to look in a different direction.

node.name: Move-lower-extremity
node.description: Move leg and/or foot.

node.name: Curl-toes
node.description: Bend toes sometimes to grip.

node.name: Hop
node.description: Jump on one foot.

node.name: Jog
node.description: Run at a trot to exercise.

node.name: Jump
node.description: Move off the ground or other surface through sudden muscular effort in the legs.

node.name: Kick
node.description: Strike out or flail with the foot or feet. Strike using the leg, in unison usually with an area of the knee or lower using the foot.

node.name: Pedal
node.description: Move by working the pedals of a bicycle or other machine.

node.name: Press-foot
node.description: Move by pressing foot.

node.name: Run
node.description: Travel on foot at a fast pace.

node.name: Step
node.description: Put one leg in front of the other and shift weight onto it.

node.name: Heel-strike
node.description: Strike the ground with the heel during a step.

node.name: Toe-off
node.description: Push with toe as part of a stride.

node.name: Trot
node.description: Run at a moderate pace, typically with short steps.

node.name: Walk
node.description: Move at a regular pace by lifting and setting down each foot in turn never having both feet off the ground at once.

node.name: Move-torso
node.description: Move body trunk.

node.name: Move-upper-extremity
node.description: Move arm, shoulder, and/or hand.

node.name: Drop
node.description: Let or cause to fall vertically.

node.name: Grab
node.description: Seize suddenly or quickly. Snatch or clutch.

node.name: Grasp
node.description: Seize and hold firmly.

node.name: Hold-down
node.description: Prevent someone or something from moving by holding them firmly.

node.name: Lift
node.description: Raising something to higher position.

node.name: Make-fist
node.description: Close hand tightly with the fingers bent against the palm.

node.name: Point
node.description: Draw attention to something by extending a finger or arm.

node.name: Press
node.description: Apply pressure to something to flatten, shape, smooth or depress it. This action tag should be used to indicate key presses and mouse clicks.

node.name: Push
node.description: Apply force in order to move something away. Use Press to indicate a key press or mouse click.

node.name: Reach
node.description: Stretch out your arm in order to get or touch something.

node.name: Release
node.description: Make available or set free.

node.name: Retract
node.description: Draw or pull back.

node.name: Scratch
node.description: Drag claws or nails over a surface or on skin.

node.name: Snap-fingers
node.description: Make a noise by pushing second finger hard against thumb and then releasing it suddenly so that it hits the base of the thumb.

node.name: Touch
node.description: Come into or be in contact with.

node.name: Perceive
node.description: Produce an internal, conscious image through stimulating a sensory system.

node.name: Hear
node.description: Give attention to a sound.

node.name: See
node.description: Direct gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.

node.name: Sense-by-touch
node.description: Sense something through receptors in the skin.

node.name: Smell
node.description: Inhale in order to ascertain an odor or scent.

node.name: Taste
node.description: Sense a flavor in the mouth and throat on contact with a substance.

node.name: Perform
node.description: Carry out or accomplish an action, task, or function.

node.name: Close
node.description: Act as to blocked against entry or passage.

node.name: Collide-with
node.description: Hit with force when moving.

node.name: Halt
node.description: Bring or come to an abrupt stop.

node.name: Modify
node.description: Change something.

node.name: Open
node.description: Widen an aperture, door, or gap, especially one allowing access to something.

node.name: Operate
node.description: Control the functioning of a machine, process, or system.

node.name: Play
node.description: Engage in activity for enjoyment and recreation rather than a serious or practical purpose.

node.name: Read
node.description: Interpret something that is written or printed.

node.name: Repeat
node.description: Make do or perform again.

node.name: Rest
node.description: Be inactive in order to regain strength, health, or energy.

node.name: Write
node.description: Communicate or express by means of letters or symbols written or imprinted on a surface.

node.name: Think
node.description: Direct the mind toward someone or something or use the mind actively to form connected ideas.

node.name: Allow
node.description: Allow access to something such as allowing a car to pass.

node.name: Attend-to
node.description: Focus mental experience on specific targets.

node.name: Count
node.description: Tally items either silently or aloud.

node.name: Deny
node.description: Refuse to give or grant something requested or desired by someone.

node.name: Detect
node.description: Discover or identify the presence or existence of something.

node.name: Discriminate
node.description: Recognize a distinction.

node.name: Encode
node.description: Convert information or an instruction into a particular form.

node.name: Evade
node.description: Escape or avoid, especially by cleverness or trickery.

node.name: Generate
node.description: Cause something, especially an emotion or situation to arise or come about.

node.name: Identify
node.description: Establish or indicate who or what someone or something is.

node.name: Imagine
node.description: Form a mental image or concept of something.

node.name: Judge
node.description: Evaluate evidence to make a decision or form a belief.

node.name: Learn
node.description: Adaptively change behavior as the result of experience.

node.name: Memorize
node.description: Adaptively change behavior as the result of experience.

node.name: Plan
node.description: Think about the activities required to achieve a desired goal.

node.name: Predict
node.description: Say or estimate that something will happen or will be a consequence of something without having exact information.

node.name: Recall
node.description: Remember information by mental effort.

node.name: Recognize
node.description: Identify someone or something from having encountered them before.

node.name: Respond
node.description: React to something such as a treatment or a stimulus.

node.name: Switch-attention
node.description: Transfer attention from one focus to another.

node.name: Track
node.description: Follow a person, animal, or object through space or time.

node.name: Artifact
node.description: When relevant for the clinical interpretation, artifacts can be scored by specifying the type and the location.

node.name: Eye-blink-artifact
node.description: Example for EEG: Fp1/Fp2 become electropositive with eye closure because the cornea is positively charged causing a negative deflection in Fp1/Fp2. If the eye blink is unilateral, consider prosthetic eye. If it is in F8 rather than Fp2 then the electrodes are plugged in wrong.

node.name: Eye-movement-horizontal-artifact
node.description: Example for EEG: There is an upward deflection in the Fp2-F8 derivation, when the eyes move to the right side. In this case F8 becomes more positive and therefore. When the eyes move to the left, F7 becomes more positive and there is an upward deflection in the Fp1-F7 derivation.

node.name: Eye-movement-vertical-artifact
node.description: Example for EEG: The EEG shows positive potentials (50-100 micro V) with bi-frontal distribution, maximum at Fp1 and Fp2, when the eyeball rotated upward. The downward rotation of the eyeball was associated with the negative deflection. The time course of the deflections was similar to the time course of the eyeball movement.

node.name: Slow-eye-movement-artifact
node.description: Slow, rolling eye-movements, seen during drowsiness.

node.name: Glossokinetic-artifact
node.description: The tongue functions as a dipole, with the tip negative with respect to the base. The artifact produced by the tongue has a broad potential field that drops from frontal to occipital areas, although it is less steep than that produced by eye movement artifacts. The amplitude of the potentials is greater inferiorly than in parasagittal regions; the frequency is variable but usually in the delta range. Chewing and sucking can produce similar artifacts.

node.name: Rocking-patting-artifact
node.description: Quasi-rhythmical artifacts in recordings from infants caused by rocking/patting.

node.name: Movement-artifact
node.description: Example for EEG: Large amplitude artifact, with irregular morphology (usually resembling a slow-wave or a wave with complex morphology) seen in one or several channels, due to movement. If the causing movement is repetitive, the artifact might resemble a rhythmic EEG activity.

node.name: Respiration-artifact
node.description: Respiration can produce 2 kinds of artifacts. One type is in the form of slow and rhythmic activity, synchronous with the body movements of respiration and mechanically affecting the impedance of (usually) one electrode. The other type can be slow or sharp waves that occur synchronously with inhalation or exhalation and involve those electrodes on which the patient is lying.

node.name: Pulse-artifact
node.description: Example for EEG: Occurs when an EEG electrode is placed over a pulsating vessel. The pulsation can cause slow waves that may simulate EEG activity. A direct relationship exists between ECG and the pulse waves (200-300 millisecond delay after ECG equals QRS complex).

node.name: ECG-artifact
node.description: Example for EEG: Far-field potential generated in the heart. The voltage and apparent surface of the artifact vary from derivation to derivation and, consequently, from montage to montage. The artifact is observed best in referential montages using earlobe electrodes A1 and A2. ECG artifact is recognized easily by its rhythmicity/regularity and coincidence with the ECG tracing.

node.name: Sweat-artifact
node.description: Is a low amplitude undulating waveform that is usually greater than 2 seconds and may appear to be an unstable baseline.

node.name: EMG-artifact
node.description: Myogenic potentials are the most common artifacts. Frontalis and temporalis muscles (ex..: clenching of jaw muscles) are common causes. Generally, the potentials generated in the muscles are of shorter duration than those generated in the brain. The frequency components are usually beyond 30-50 Hz, and the bursts are arrhythmic.

node.name: Power-supply-artifact
node.description: 50-60 Hz artifact. Monomorphic waveform due to 50 or 60 Hz A/C power supply.

node.name: Induction-artifact
node.description: Artifacts (usually of high frequency) induced by nearby equipment (like in the intensive care unit).

node.name: Electrode-pops-artifact
node.description: Are brief discharges with a very steep upslope and shallow fall that occur in all leads which include that electrode.

node.name: Salt-bridge-artifact
node.description: Typically occurs in 1 channel which may appear isoelectric. Only seen in bipolar montage.
Free text.

node.name: Critically-ill-patients-patterns
node.description: Rhythmic or periodic patterns in critically ill patients (RPPs) are scored according to the 2012 version of the American Clinical Neurophysiology Society Standardized Critical Care EEG Terminology (Hirsch et al., 2013).

node.name: Critically-ill-patients-periodic-discharges
node.description: Periodic discharges (PDs).

node.name: Rhythmic-delta-activity
node.description: RDA

node.name: Spike-or-sharp-and-wave
node.description: SW

node.name: Episode
node.description: Clinical episode or electrographic seizure.

node.name: Epileptic-seizure
node.description: The ILAE presented a revised seizure classification that divides seizures into focal, generalized onset, or unknown onset.

node.name: Focal-onset-epileptic-seizure
node.description: Focal seizures can be divided into focal aware and impaired awareness seizures, with additional motor and nonmotor classifications.

node.name: Focal-to-bilateral-tonic-clonic-focal-onset-epileptic-seizure
node.description: A seizure type with focal onset, with awareness or impaired awareness, either motor or non-motor, progressing to bilateral tonic clonic activity. The prior term was seizure with partial onset with secondary generalization. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Generalized-onset-epileptic-seizure
node.description: Generalized-onset seizures are classified as motor or nonmotor (absence), without using awareness level as a classifier, as most but not all of these seizures are linked with impaired awareness.

node.name: Unknown-onset-epileptic-seizure
node.description: Even if the onset of seizures is unknown, they may exhibit characteristics that fall into categories such as motor, nonmotor, tonic-clonic, epileptic spasms, or behavior arrest.

node.name: Unclassified-epileptic-seizure
node.description: Referring to a seizure type that cannot be described by the ILAE 2017 classification either because of inadequate information or unusual clinical features.

node.name: Subtle-seizure
node.description: Seizure type frequent in neonates, sometimes referred to as motor automatisms; they may include random and roving eye movements, sucking, chewing motions, tongue protrusion, rowing or swimming or boxing movements of the arms, pedaling and bicycling movements of the lower limbs; apneic seizures are relatively common. Although some subtle seizures are associated with rhythmic ictal EEG discharges, and are clearly epileptic, ictal EEG often does not show typical epileptic activity.

node.name: Electrographic-seizure
node.description: Referred usually to non convulsive status. Ictal EEG: rhythmic discharge or spike and wave pattern with definite evolution in frequency, location, or morphology lasting at least 10 s; evolution in amplitude alone did not qualify.

node.name: Seizure-PNES
node.description: Psychogenic non-epileptic seizure.

node.name: Sleep-related-arousal
node.description: Normal.

node.name: Benign-sleep-myoclonus
node.description: A distinctive disorder of sleep characterized by a) neonatal onset, b) rhythmic myoclonic jerks only during sleep and c) abrupt and consistent cessation with arousal, d) absence of concomitant electrographic changes suggestive of seizures, and e) good outcome.

node.name: Confusional-awakening
node.description: Episode of non epileptic nature included in NREM parasomnias, characterized by sudden arousal and complex behavior but without full alertness, usually lasting a few minutes and occurring almost in all children at least occasionally. Amnesia of the episode is the rule.

node.name: Sleep-periodic-limb-movement
node.description: PLMS. Periodic limb movement in sleep. Episodes are characterized by brief (0.5- to 5.0-second) lower-extremity movements during sleep, which typically occur at 20- to 40-second intervals, most commonly during the first 3 hours of sleep. The affected individual is usually not aware of the movements or of the transient partial arousals.

node.name: REM-sleep-behavioral-disorder
node.description: REM sleep behavioral disorder. Episodes characterized by: a) presence of REM sleep without atonia (RSWA) on polysomnography (PSG); b) presence of at least 1 of the following conditions - (1) Sleep-related behaviors, by history, that have been injurious, potentially injurious, or disruptive (example: dream enactment behavior); (2) abnormal REM sleep behavior documented during PSG monitoring; (3) absence of epileptiform activity on electroencephalogram (EEG) during REM sleep (unless RBD can be clearly distinguished from any concurrent REM sleep-related seizure disorder); (4) sleep disorder not better explained by another sleep disorder, a medical or neurologic disorder, a mental disorder, medication use, or a substance use disorder.

node.name: Sleep-walking
node.description: Episodes characterized by ambulation during sleep; the patient is difficult to arouse during an episode, and is usually amnesic following the episode. Episodes usually occur in the first third of the night during slow wave sleep. Polysomnographic recordings demonstrate 2 abnormalities during the first sleep cycle: frequent, brief, non-behavioral EEG-defined arousals prior to the somnambulistic episode and abnormally low gamma (0.75-2.0 Hz) EEG power on spectral analysis, correlating with high-voltage (hyper-synchronic gamma) waves lasting 10 to 15 s occurring just prior to the movement. This is followed by stage I NREM sleep, and there is no evidence of complete awakening.

node.name: Hyperekplexia
node.description: Disorder characterized by exaggerated startle response and hypertonicity that may occur during the first year of life and in severe cases during the neonatal period. Children usually present with marked irritability and recurrent startles in response to handling and sounds. Severely affected infants can have severe jerks and stiffening, sometimes with breath-holding spells.

node.name: Jactatio-capitis-nocturna
node.description: Relatively common in normal children at the time of going to bed, especially during the first year of life, the rhythmic head movements persist during sleep. Usually, these phenomena disappear before 3 years of age.

node.name: Pavor-nocturnus
node.description: A nocturnal episode characterized by age of onset of less than five years (mean age 18 months, with peak prevalence at five to seven years), appearance of signs of panic two hours after falling asleep with crying, screams, a fearful expression, inability to recognize other people including parents (for a duration of 5-15 minutes), amnesia upon awakening. Pavor nocturnus occurs in patients almost every night for months or years (but the frequency is highly variable and may be as low as once a month) and is likely to disappear spontaneously at the age of six to eight years.

node.name: Pediatric-stereotypical-behavior-episode
node.description: Repetitive motor behavior in children, typically rhythmic and persistent; usually not paroxysmal and rarely suggest epilepsy. They include headbanging, head-rolling, jactatio capitis nocturna, body rocking, buccal or lingual movements, hand flapping and related mannerisms, repetitive hand-waving (to self-induce photosensitive seizures).

node.name: Paroxysmal-motor-event
node.description: Paroxysmal phenomena during neonatal or childhood periods characterized by recurrent motor or behavioral signs or symptoms that must be distinguishes from epileptic disorders.

node.name: Syncope
node.description: Episode with loss of consciousness and muscle tone that is abrupt in onset, of short duration and followed by rapid recovery; it occurs in response to transient impairment of cerebral perfusion. Typical prodromal symptoms often herald onset of syncope and postictal symptoms are minimal. Syncopal convulsions resulting from cerebral anoxia are common but are not a form of epilepsy, nor are there any accompanying EEG ictal discharges.

node.name: Cataplexy
node.description: A sudden decrement in muscle tone and loss of deep tendon reflexes, leading to muscle weakness, paralysis, or postural collapse. Cataplexy usually is precipitated by an outburst of emotional expression-notably laughter, anger, or startle. It is one of the tetrad of symptoms of narcolepsy. During cataplexy, respiration and voluntary eye movements are not compromised. Consciousness is preserved.
Free text.

node.name: Finding-property
node.description: Descriptive element similar to main HED /Property. Something that pertains to a thing. A characteristic of some entity. A quality or feature regarded as a characteristic or inherent part of someone or something. HED attributes are adjectives or adverbs.

node.name: Rhythmic-activity-morphology
node.description: EEG activity consisting of a sequence of waves approximately constant period.

node.name: Delta-activity-morphology
node.description: EEG rhythm in the delta (under 4 Hz) range that does not belong to the posterior dominant rhythm (scored under other organized rhythms).
Free text.

node.name: Theta-activity-morphology
node.description: EEG rhythm in the theta (4-8 Hz) range that does not belong to the posterior dominant rhythm (scored under other organized rhythm).
Free text.

node.name: Alpha-activity-morphology
node.description: EEG rhythm in the alpha range (8-13 Hz) which is considered part of the background (ongoing) activity but does not fulfill the criteria of the posterior dominant rhythm (alpha rhythm).
Free text.

node.name: Beta-activity-morphology
node.description: EEG rhythm between 14 and 40 Hz, which is considered part of the background (ongoing) activity but does not fulfill the criteria of the posterior dominant rhythm. Most characteristically: a rhythm from 14 to 40 Hz recorded over the fronto-central regions of the head during wakefulness. Amplitude of the beta rhythm varies but is mostly below 30 microV. Other beta rhythms are most prominent in other locations or are diffuse.
Free text.
Free text.

node.name: Spike-morphology
node.description: A transient, clearly distinguished from background activity, with pointed peak at a conventional paper speed or time scale and duration from 20 to under 70 ms, i.e. 1/50-1/15 s approximately. Main component is generally negative relative to other areas. Amplitude varies.
Free text.

node.name: Spike-and-slow-wave-morphology
node.description: A pattern consisting of a spike followed by a slow wave.
Free text.

node.name: Runs-of-rapid-spikes-morphology
node.description: Bursts of spike discharges at a rate from 10 to 25/sec (in most cases somewhat irregular). The bursts last more than 2 seconds (usually 2 to 10 seconds) and it is typically seen in sleep. Synonyms: rhythmic spikes, generalized paroxysmal fast activity, fast paroxysmal rhythms, grand mal discharge, fast beta activity.
Free text.

node.name: Polyspikes-morphology
node.description: Two or more consecutive spikes.
Free text.

node.name: Polyspike-and-slow-wave-morphology
node.description: Two or more consecutive spikes associated with one or more slow waves.
Free text.

node.name: Sharp-wave-morphology
node.description: A transient clearly distinguished from background activity, with pointed peak at a conventional paper speed or time scale, and duration of 70-200 ms, i.e. over 1/4-1/5 s approximately. Main component is generally negative relative to other areas. Amplitude varies.
Free text.

node.name: Sharp-and-slow-wave-morphology
node.description: A sequence of a sharp wave and a slow wave.
Free text.

node.name: Slow-sharp-wave-morphology
node.description: A transient that bears all the characteristics of a sharp-wave, but exceeds 200 ms. Synonym: blunted sharp wave.
Free text.

node.name: High-frequency-oscillation-morphology
node.description: HFO.
Free text.

node.name: Hypsarrhythmia-classic-morphology
node.description: Abnormal interictal high amplitude waves and a background of irregular spikes.
Free text.
Free text.

node.name: Fast-spike-activity-morphology
node.description: A burst consisting of a sequence of spikes. Duration greater than 1 s. Frequency at least in the alpha range.
Free text.

node.name: Low-voltage-fast-activity-morphology
node.description: Refers to the fast, and often recruiting activity which can be recorded at the onset of an ictal discharge, particularly in invasive EEG recording of a seizure.
Free text.

node.name: Polysharp-waves-morphology
node.description: A sequence of two or more sharp-waves.
Free text.
Free text.

node.name: Irregular-delta-or-theta-activity-morphology
node.description: EEG activity consisting of repetitive waves of inconsistent wave-duration but in delta and/or theta rang (greater than 125 ms).
Free text.

node.name: Electrodecremental-change-morphology
node.description: Sudden desynchronization of electrical activity.
Free text.

node.name: DC-shift-morphology
node.description: Shift of negative polarity of the direct current recordings, during seizures.
Free text.

node.name: Disappearance-of-ongoing-activity-morphology
node.description: Disappearance of the EEG activity that preceded the ictal event but still remnants of background activity (thus not enough to name it electrodecremental change).
Free text.

node.name: Polymorphic-delta-activity-morphology
node.description: EEG activity consisting of waves in the delta range (over 250 ms duration for each wave) but of different morphology.
Free text.

node.name: Frontal-intermittent-rhythmic-delta-activity-morphology
node.description: Frontal intermittent rhythmic delta activity (FIRDA). Fairly regular or approximately sinusoidal waves, mostly occurring in bursts at 1.5-2.5 Hz over the frontal areas of one or both sides of the head. Comment: most commonly associated with unspecified encephalopathy, in adults.
Free text.

node.name: Occipital-intermittent-rhythmic-delta-activity-morphology
node.description: Occipital intermittent rhythmic delta activity (OIRDA). Fairly regular or approximately sinusoidal waves, mostly occurring in bursts at 2-3 Hz over the occipital or posterior head regions of one or both sides of the head. Frequently blocked or attenuated by opening the eyes. Comment: most commonly associated with unspecified encephalopathy, in children.
Free text.

node.name: Temporal-intermittent-rhythmic-delta-activity-morphology
node.description: Temporal intermittent rhythmic delta activity (TIRDA). Fairly regular or approximately sinusoidal waves, mostly occurring in bursts at over the temporal areas of one side of the head. Comment: most commonly associated with temporal lobe epilepsy.
Free text.

node.name: Periodic-discharge-morphology
node.description: Periodic discharges not further specified (PDs).

node.name: Multifocal-finding

node.name: Time-related-property
node.description: Important to estimate how often an interictal abnormality is seen in the recording.

node.name: Appearance-mode
node.description: Describes how the non-ictal EEG pattern/graphoelement is distributed through the recording.

node.name: Random-appearance-mode
node.description: Occurrence of the non-ictal EEG pattern / graphoelement without any rhythmicity / periodicity.
Free text.

node.name: Periodic-appearance-mode
node.description: Non-ictal EEG pattern / graphoelement occurring at an approximately regular rate / interval (generally of 1 to several seconds).
Free text.

node.name: Variable-appearance-mode
node.description: Occurrence of non-ictal EEG pattern / graphoelements, that is sometimes rhythmic or periodic, other times random, throughout the recording.

node.name: Discharge-pattern
node.description: Describes the organization of the EEG signal within the discharge (distinguish between single and repetitive discharges)

node.name: Single-discharge-pattern
node.description: Applies to the intra-burst pattern: a graphoelement that is not repetitive; before and after the graphoelement one can distinguish the background activity.

node.name: Rhythmic-trains-or-bursts-discharge-pattern
node.description: Applies to the intra-burst pattern: a non-ictal graphoelement that repeats itself without returning to the background activity between them. The graphoelements within this repetition occur at approximately constant period.

node.name: Arrhythmic-trains-or-bursts-discharge-pattern
node.description: Applies to the intra-burst pattern: a non-ictal graphoelement that repeats itself without returning to the background activity between them. The graphoelements within this repetition occur at inconstant period.
