node.name: Seizure-classification
node.description: Seizure classification refers to the grouping of seizures based on their clinical features, EEG patterns, and other characteristics. Epileptic seizures are named using the current ILAE seizure classification (Fisher et al., 2017, Beniczky et al., 2017).

node.name: Motor-seizure
node.description: Involves musculature in any form. The motor event could consist of an increase (positive) or decrease (negative) in muscle contraction to produce a movement. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Myoclonic-motor-seizure
node.description: Sudden, brief ( lower than 100 msec) involuntary single or multiple contraction(s) of muscles(s) or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal). Myoclonus is less regularly repetitive and less sustained than is clonus. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Clonic-motor-seizure
node.description: Jerking, either symmetric or asymmetric, that is regularly repetitive and involves the same muscle groups. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Tonic-motor-seizure
node.description: A sustained increase in muscle contraction lasting a few seconds to minutes. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Atonic-motor-seizure
node.description: Sudden loss or diminution of muscle tone without apparent preceding myoclonic or tonic event lasting about 1 to 2 s, involving head, trunk, jaw, or limb musculature. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Myoclonic-atonic-motor-seizure
node.description: A generalized seizure type with a myoclonic jerk leading to an atonic motor component. This type was previously called myoclonic astatic. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Myoclonic-tonic-clonic-motor-seizure
node.description: One or a few jerks of limbs bilaterally, followed by a tonic clonic seizure. The initial jerks can be considered to be either a brief period of clonus or myoclonus. Seizures with this characteristic are common in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Tonic-clonic-motor-seizure
node.description: A sequence consisting of a tonic followed by a clonic phase. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Automatism-motor-seizure
node.description: A more or less coordinated motor activity usually occurring when cognition is impaired and for which the subject is usually (but not always) amnesic afterward. This often resembles a voluntary movement and may consist of an inappropriate continuation of preictal motor activity. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Epileptic-spasm-episode
node.description: A sudden flexion, extension, or mixed extension flexion of predominantly proximal and truncal muscles that is usually more sustained than a myoclonic movement but not as sustained as a tonic seizure. Limited forms may occur: Grimacing, head nodding, or subtle eye movements. Epileptic spasms frequently occur in clusters. Infantile spasms are the best known form, but spasms can occur at all ages. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Nonmotor-seizure
node.description: Focal or generalized seizure types in which motor activity is not prominent. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Behavior-arrest-nonmotor-seizure
node.description: Arrest (pause) of activities, freezing, immobilization, as in behavior arrest seizure. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Sensory-nonmotor-seizure
node.description: A perceptual experience not caused by appropriate stimuli in the external world. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Emotional-nonmotor-seizure
node.description: Seizures presenting with an emotion or the appearance of having an emotion as an early prominent feature, such as fear, spontaneous joy or euphoria, laughing (gelastic), or crying (dacrystic). Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Cognitive-nonmotor-seizure
node.description: Pertaining to thinking and higher cortical functions, such as language, spatial perception, memory, and praxis. The previous term for similar usage as a seizure type was psychic. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Autonomic-nonmotor-seizure
node.description: A distinct alteration of autonomic nervous system function involving cardiovascular, pupillary, gastrointestinal, sudomotor, vasomotor, and thermoregulatory functions. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Absence-seizure
node.description: Absence seizures present with a sudden cessation of activity and awareness. Absence seizures tend to occur in younger age groups, have more sudden start and termination, and they usually display less complex automatisms than do focal seizures with impaired awareness, but the distinctions are not absolute. EEG information may be required for accurate classification. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Typical-absence-seizure
node.description: A sudden onset, interruption of ongoing activities, a blank stare, possibly a brief upward deviation of the eyes. Usually the patient will be unresponsive when spoken to. Duration is a few seconds to half a minute with very rapid recovery. Although not always available, an EEG would show generalized epileptiform discharges during the event. An absence seizure is by definition a seizure of generalized onset. The word is not synonymous with a blank stare, which also can be encountered with focal onset seizures. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Atypical-absence-seizure
node.description: An absence seizure with changes in tone that are more pronounced than in typical absence or the onset and/or cessation is not abrupt, often associated with slow, irregular, generalized spike-wave activity. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Myoclonic-absence-seizure
node.description: A myoclonic absence seizure refers to an absence seizure with rhythmic three-per-second myoclonic movements, causing ratcheting abduction of the upper limbs leading to progressive arm elevation, and associated with three-per-second generalized spike-wave discharges. Duration is typically 10 to 60 s. Impairment of consciousness may not be obvious. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Eyelid-myoclonia-absence-seizure
node.description: Eyelid myoclonia are myoclonic jerks of the eyelids and upward deviation of the eyes, often precipitated by closing the eyes or by light. Eyelid myoclonia can be associated with absences, but also can be motor seizures without a corresponding absence, making them difficult to categorize. The 2017 classification groups them with nonmotor (absence) seizures, which may seem counterintuitive, but the myoclonia in this instance is meant to link with absence, rather than with nonmotor. Definition from ILAE 2017 Classification of Seizure Types Expanded Version

node.name: Episode-phase
node.description: The electroclinical findings (i.e., the seizure semiology and the ictal EEG) are divided in three phases: onset, propagation, and postictal.

node.name: Seizure-semiology-manifestation
node.description: Seizure semiology refers to the clinical features or signs that are observed during a seizure, such as the type of movements or behaviors exhibited by the person having the seizure, the duration of the seizure, the level of consciousness, and any associated symptoms such as aura or postictal confusion. In other words, seizure semiology describes the physical manifestations of a seizure. Semiology is described according to the ILAE Glossary of Descriptive Terminology for Ictal Semiology (Blume et al., 2001). Besides the name, the semiologic finding can also be characterized by the somatotopic modifier, laterality, body part and centricity. Uses Location-property tags.

node.name: Semiology-motor-tonic
node.description: A sustained increase in muscle contraction lasting a few seconds to minutes.

node.name: Semiology-motor-dystonic
node.description: Sustained contractions of both agonist and antagonist muscles producing athetoid or twisting movements, which, when prolonged, may produce abnormal postures.

node.name: Semiology-motor-epileptic-spasm
node.description: A sudden flexion, extension, or mixed extension flexion of predominantly proximal and truncal muscles that is usually more sustained than a myoclonic movement but not so sustained as a tonic seizure (i.e., about 1 s). Limited forms may occur: grimacing, head nodding. Frequent occurrence in clusters.

node.name: Semiology-motor-postural
node.description: Adoption of a posture that may be bilaterally symmetric or asymmetric (as in a fencing posture).

node.name: Semiology-motor-versive
node.description: A sustained, forced conjugate ocular, cephalic, and/or truncal rotation or lateral deviation from the midline.

node.name: Semiology-motor-clonic
node.description: Myoclonus that is regularly repetitive, involves the same muscle groups, at a frequency of about 2 to 3 c/s, and is prolonged. Synonym: rhythmic myoclonus .

node.name: Semiology-motor-myoclonic
node.description: Characterized by myoclonus. MYOCLONUS : sudden, brief (lower than 100 ms) involuntary single or multiple contraction(s) of muscles(s) or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal).

node.name: Semiology-motor-jacksonian-march
node.description: Term indicating spread of clonic movements through contiguous body parts unilaterally.

node.name: Semiology-motor-negative-myoclonus
node.description: Characterized by negative myoclonus. NEGATIVE MYOCLONUS: interruption of tonic muscular activity for lower than 500 ms without evidence of preceding myoclonia.

node.name: Semiology-motor-tonic-clonic
node.description: A sequence consisting of a tonic followed by a clonic phase. Variants such as clonic-tonic-clonic may be seen. Asymmetry of limb posture during the tonic phase of a GTC: one arm is rigidly extended at the elbow (often with the fist clenched tightly and flexed at the wrist), whereas the opposite arm is flexed at the elbow.

node.name: Semiology-motor-astatic
node.description: Loss of erect posture that results from an atonic, myoclonic, or tonic mechanism. Synonym: drop attack.

node.name: Semiology-motor-atonic
node.description: Sudden loss or diminution of muscle tone without apparent preceding myoclonic or tonic event lasting greater or equal to 1 to 2 s, involving head, trunk, jaw, or limb musculature.
Free text.

node.name: Semiology-motor-automatisms-mimetic
node.description: Facial expression suggesting an emotional state, often fear.

node.name: Semiology-motor-automatisms-oroalimentary
node.description: Lip smacking, lip pursing, chewing, licking, tooth grinding, or swallowing.

node.name: Semiology-motor-automatisms-dacrystic
node.description: Bursts of crying.

node.name: Semiology-motor-automatisms-dyspraxic
node.description: Inability to perform learned movements spontaneously or on command or imitation despite intact relevant motor and sensory systems and adequate comprehension and cooperation.

node.name: Semiology-motor-automatisms-manual
node.description: 1. Indicates principally distal components, bilateral or unilateral. 2. Fumbling, tapping, manipulating movements.

node.name: Semiology-motor-automatisms-gestural
node.description: Semipurposive, asynchronous hand movements. Often unilateral.

node.name: Semiology-motor-automatisms-pedal
node.description: 1. Indicates principally distal components, bilateral or unilateral. 2. Fumbling, tapping, manipulating movements.

node.name: Semiology-motor-automatisms-hypermotor
node.description: 1. Involves predominantly proximal limb or axial muscles producing irregular sequential ballistic movements, such as pedaling, pelvic thrusting, thrashing, rocking movements. 2. Increase in rate of ongoing movements or inappropriately rapid performance of a movement.

node.name: Semiology-motor-automatisms-hypokinetic
node.description: A decrease in amplitude and/or rate or arrest of ongoing motor activity.

node.name: Semiology-motor-automatisms-gelastic
node.description: Bursts of laughter or giggling, usually without an appropriate affective tone.
Free text.

node.name: Semiology-motor-behavioral-arrest
node.description: Interruption of ongoing motor activity or of ongoing behaviors with fixed gaze, without movement of the head or trunk (oro-alimentary and hand automatisms may continue).

node.name: Semiology-sensory-headache
node.description: Headache occurring in close temporal proximity to the seizure or as the sole seizure manifestation.

node.name: Semiology-sensory-visual
node.description: Flashing or flickering lights, spots, simple patterns, scotomata, or amaurosis.

node.name: Semiology-sensory-auditory
node.description: Buzzing, drumming sounds or single tones.

node.name: Semiology-sensory-gustatory
node.description: Taste sensations including acidic, bitter, salty, sweet, or metallic.

node.name: Semiology-sensory-epigastric
node.description: Abdominal discomfort including nausea, emptiness, tightness, churning, butterflies, malaise, pain, and hunger; sensation may rise to chest or throat. Some phenomena may reflect ictal autonomic dysfunction.

node.name: Semiology-sensory-somatosensory
node.description: Tingling, numbness, electric-shock sensation, sense of movement or desire to move.

node.name: Semiology-sensory-painful
node.description: Peripheral (lateralized/bilateral), cephalic, abdominal.

node.name: Semiology-sensory-autonomic-sensation
node.description: A sensation consistent with involvement of the autonomic nervous system, including cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, sudomotor, vasomotor, and thermoregulatory functions. (Thus autonomic aura; cf. autonomic events 3.0).
Free text.

node.name: Semiology-experiential-affective-emotional
node.description: Components include fear, depression, joy, and (rarely) anger.

node.name: Semiology-experiential-hallucinatory
node.description: Composite perceptions without corresponding external stimuli involving visual, auditory, somatosensory, olfactory, and/or gustatory phenomena. Example: hearing and seeing people talking.

node.name: Semiology-experiential-illusory
node.description: An alteration of actual percepts involving the visual, auditory, somatosensory, olfactory, or gustatory systems.

node.name: Semiology-experiential-mnemonic
node.description: Components that reflect ictal dysmnesia such as feelings of familiarity (deja-vu) and unfamiliarity (jamais-vu).
Free text.

node.name: Semiology-dyscognitive
node.description: The term describes events in which (1) disturbance of cognition is the predominant or most apparent feature, and (2a) two or more of the following components are involved, or (2b) involvement of such components remains undetermined. Otherwise, use the more specific term (e.g., mnemonic experiential seizure or hallucinatory experiential seizure). Components of cognition: ++ perception: symbolic conception of sensory information ++ attention: appropriate selection of a principal perception or task ++ emotion: appropriate affective significance of a perception ++ memory: ability to store and retrieve percepts or concepts ++ executive function: anticipation, selection, monitoring of consequences, and initiation of motor activity including praxis, speech.
Free text.

node.name: Semiology-autonomic-pupillary
node.description: Mydriasis, miosis (either bilateral or unilateral).

node.name: Semiology-autonomic-hypersalivation
node.description: Increase in production of saliva leading to uncontrollable drooling

node.name: Semiology-autonomic-respiratory-apnoeic
node.description: subjective shortness of breath, hyperventilation, stridor, coughing, choking, apnea, oxygen desaturation, neurogenic pulmonary edema.

node.name: Semiology-autonomic-cardiovascular
node.description: Modifications of heart rate (tachycardia, bradycardia), cardiac arrhythmias (such as sinus arrhythmia, sinus arrest, supraventricular tachycardia, atrial premature depolarizations, ventricular premature depolarizations, atrio-ventricular block, bundle branch block, atrioventricular nodal escape rhythm, asystole).

node.name: Semiology-autonomic-gastrointestinal
node.description: Nausea, eructation, vomiting, retching, abdominal sensations, abdominal pain, flatulence, spitting, diarrhea.

node.name: Semiology-autonomic-urinary-incontinence
node.description: urinary urge (intense urinary urge at the beginning of seizures), urinary incontinence, ictal urination (rare symptom of partial seizures without loss of consciousness).

node.name: Semiology-autonomic-genital
node.description: Sexual auras (erotic thoughts and feelings, sexual arousal and orgasm). Genital auras (unpleasant, sometimes painful, frightening or emotionally neutral somatosensory sensations in the genitals that can be accompanied by ictal orgasm). Sexual automatisms (hypermotor movements consisting of writhing, thrusting, rhythmic movements of the pelvis, arms and legs, sometimes associated with picking and rhythmic manipulation of the groin or genitalia, exhibitionism and masturbation).

node.name: Semiology-autonomic-vasomotor
node.description: Flushing or pallor (may be accompanied by feelings of warmth, cold and pain).

node.name: Semiology-autonomic-sudomotor
node.description: Sweating and piloerection (may be accompanied by feelings of warmth, cold and pain).

node.name: Semiology-autonomic-thermoregulatory
node.description: Hyperthermia, fever.
Free text.
Free text.

node.name: Postictal-semiology-quick-recovery-of-consciousness
node.description: Quick recovery of awareness and responsiveness.

node.name: Postictal-semiology-aphasia-or-dysphasia
node.description: Impaired communication involving language without dysfunction of relevant primary motor or sensory pathways, manifested as impaired comprehension, anomia, parahasic errors or a combination of these.

node.name: Postictal-semiology-behavioral-change
node.description: Occurring immediately after a aseizure. Including psychosis, hypomanina, obsessive-compulsive behavior.

node.name: Postictal-semiology-hemianopia
node.description: Postictal visual loss in a a hemi field.

node.name: Postictal-semiology-impaired-cognition
node.description: Decreased Cognitive performance involving one or more of perception, attention, emotion, memory, execution, praxis, speech.

node.name: Postictal-semiology-dysphoria
node.description: Depression, irritability, euphoric mood, fear, anxiety.

node.name: Postictal-semiology-headache
node.description: Headache with features of tension-type or migraine headache that develops within 3 h following the seizure and resolves within 72 h after seizure.

node.name: Postictal-semiology-nose-wiping
node.description: Noes-wiping usually within 60 sec of seizure offset, usually with the hand ipsilateral to the seizure onset.

node.name: Postictal-semiology-anterograde-amnesia
node.description: Impaired ability to remember new material.

node.name: Postictal-semiology-retrograde-amnesia
node.description: Impaired ability to recall previously remember material.

node.name: Postictal-semiology-paresis
node.description: Todds palsy. Any unilateral postictal dysfunction relating to motor, language, sensory and/or integrative functions.

node.name: Postictal-semiology-sleep
node.description: Invincible need to sleep after a seizure.

node.name: Postictal-semiology-unilateral-myoclonic-jerks
node.description: unilateral motor phenomena, other then specified, occurring in postictal phase.
Free text.

node.name: Ictal-EEG-patterns-obscured-by-artifacts
node.description: The interpretation of the EEG is not possible due to artifacts.
Free text.

node.name: Episode-time-context-property
node.description: Additional clinically relevant features related to episodes can be scored under timing and context. If needed, episode duration can be tagged with base schema /Property/Data-property/Data-value/Spatiotemporal-value/Temporal-value/Duration.
Free text.
Free text.
Free text.
Free text.
Free text.

node.name: Clinical-start-followed-EEG
node.description: Clinical start, followed by EEG start by X seconds.

node.name: EEG-start-followed-clinical
node.description: EEG start, followed by clinical start by X seconds.

node.name: Clinical-EEG-temporal-relationship-notes
node.description: Clinical notes to annotate the clinical-EEG temporal relationship.

node.name: Episode-event-count
node.description: Number of stereotypical episodes during the recording.

node.name: State-episode-start
node.description: State at the start of the episode.
Free text.
Free text.

node.name: Episode-prodrome
node.description: Prodrome is a preictal phenomenon, and it is defined as a subjective or objective clinical alteration (e.g., ill-localized sensation or agitation) that heralds the onset of an epileptic seizure but does not form part of it (Blume et al., 2001). Therefore, prodrome should be distinguished from aura (which is an ictal phenomenon).
Free text.
Free text.
Free text.
Free text.
Free text.
Free text.

node.name: Seizure-dynamics
node.description: Spatiotemporal dynamics can be scored (evolution in morphology; evolution in frequency; evolution in location).
Free text.
Free text.
Free text.

node.name: Seizure-dynamics-not-possible-to-determine
node.description: Not possible to determine.
Free text.

node.name: Artifact-significance-to-recording
node.description: It is important to score the significance of the described artifacts: recording is not interpretable, recording of reduced diagnostic value, does not interfere with the interpretation of the recording.
Free text.
Free text.
Free text.

node.name: Finding-significance-to-recording
node.description: Significance of finding. When normal/abnormal could be labeled with base schema Normal/Abnormal tags.
Free text.

node.name: Finding-significance-not-possible-to-determine
node.description: Not possible to determine.
Free text.

node.name: Finding-frequency
node.description: Value in Hz (number) typed in.

node.name: Finding-amplitude
node.description: Value in microvolts (number) typed in.

node.name: Finding-amplitude-asymmetry
node.description: For posterior dominant rhythm: a difference in amplitude between the homologous area on opposite sides of the head that consistently exceeds 50 percent. When symmetrical could be labeled with base schema Symmetrical tag. For sleep: Absence or consistently marked amplitude asymmetry (greater than 50 percent) of a normal sleep graphoelement.

node.name: Finding-amplitude-asymmetry-lower-left
node.description: Amplitude lower on the left side.
Free text.

node.name: Finding-amplitude-asymmetry-lower-right
node.description: Amplitude lower on the right side.
Free text.

node.name: Finding-amplitude-asymmetry-not-possible-to-determine
node.description: Not possible to determine.
Free text.
Free text.
Free text.
Free text.

node.name: Property-not-possible-to-determine
node.description: Not possible to determine.
Free text.
Free text.
Free text.

node.name: Interictal-finding
node.description: EEG pattern / transient that is distinguished form the background activity, considered abnormal, but is not recorded during ictal period (seizure) or postictal period; the presence of an interictal finding does not necessarily imply that the patient has epilepsy.

node.name: Interictal-periodic-discharges
node.description: Periodic discharge not further specified (PDs).

node.name: Generalized-periodic-discharges
node.description: GPDs.

node.name: Lateralized-periodic-discharges
node.description: LPDs.

node.name: Bilateral-independent-periodic-discharges
node.description: BIPDs.

node.name: Multifocal-periodic-discharges
node.description: MfPDs.

node.name: Item
node.description: An independently existing thing (living or nonliving).

node.name: Biological-item
node.description: An entity that is biological, that is related to living organisms.

node.name: Anatomical-item
node.description: A biological structure, system, fluid or other substance excluding single molecular entities.

node.name: Body
node.description: The biological structure representing an organism.

node.name: Body-part
node.description: Any part of an organism.

node.name: Head
node.description: The upper part of the human body, or the front or upper part of the body of an animal, typically separated from the rest of the body by a neck, and containing the brain, mouth, and sense organs.

node.name: Ear
node.description: A sense organ needed for the detection of sound and for establishing balance.

node.name: Face
node.description: The anterior portion of the head extending from the forehead to the chin and ear to ear. The facial structures contain the eyes, nose and mouth, cheeks and jaws.

node.name: Cheek
node.description: The fleshy part of the face bounded by the eyes, nose, ear, and jaw line.

node.name: Chin
node.description: The part of the face below the lower lip and including the protruding part of the lower jaw.

node.name: Eye
node.description: The organ of sight or vision.

node.name: Eyebrow
node.description: The arched strip of hair on the bony ridge above each eye socket.

node.name: Forehead
node.description: The part of the face between the eyebrows and the normal hairline.

node.name: Lip
node.description: Fleshy fold which surrounds the opening of the mouth.

node.name: Mouth
node.description: The proximal portion of the digestive tract, containing the oral cavity and bounded by the oral opening.

node.name: Nose
node.description: A structure of special sense serving as an organ of the sense of smell and as an entrance to the respiratory tract.

node.name: Teeth
node.description: The hard bonelike structures in the jaws. A collection of teeth arranged in some pattern in the mouth or other part of the body.

node.name: Hair
node.description: The filamentous outgrowth of the epidermis.

node.name: Lower-extremity
node.description: Refers to the whole inferior limb (leg and/or foot).

node.name: Ankle
node.description: A gliding joint between the distal ends of the tibia and fibula and the proximal end of the talus.

node.name: Calf
node.description: The fleshy part at the back of the leg below the knee.

node.name: Foot
node.description: The structure found below the ankle joint required for locomotion.

node.name: Big-toe
node.description: The largest toe on the inner side of the foot.

node.name: Heel
node.description: The back of the foot below the ankle.

node.name: Instep
node.description: The part of the foot between the ball and the heel on the inner side.

node.name: Little-toe
node.description: The smallest toe located on the outer side of the foot.

node.name: Toes
node.description: The terminal digits of the foot.

node.name: Knee
node.description: A joint connecting the lower part of the femur with the upper part of the tibia.

node.name: Shin
node.description: Front part of the leg below the knee.

node.name: Thigh
node.description: Upper part of the leg between hip and knee.

node.name: Torso
node.description: The body excluding the head and neck and limbs.

node.name: Buttocks
node.description: The round fleshy parts that form the lower rear area of a human trunk.

node.name: Gentalia
node.description: The external organs of reproduction.

node.name: Hip
node.description: The lateral prominence of the pelvis from the waist to the thigh.

node.name: Torso-back
node.description: The rear surface of the human body from the shoulders to the hips.

node.name: Torso-chest
node.description: The anterior side of the thorax from the neck to the abdomen.

node.name: Waist
node.description: The abdominal circumference at the navel.

node.name: Upper-extremity
node.description: Refers to the whole superior limb (shoulder, arm, elbow, wrist, hand).

node.name: Elbow
node.description: A type of hinge joint located between the forearm and upper arm.

node.name: Forearm
node.description: Lower part of the arm between the elbow and wrist.

node.name: Hand
node.description: The distal portion of the upper extremity. It consists of the carpus, metacarpus, and digits.

node.name: Finger
node.description: Any of the digits of the hand.

node.name: Index-finger
node.description: The second finger from the radial side of the hand, next to the thumb.

node.name: Little-finger
node.description: The fifth and smallest finger from the radial side of the hand.

node.name: Middle-finger
node.description: The middle or third finger from the radial side of the hand.

node.name: Ring-finger
node.description: The fourth finger from the radial side of the hand.

node.name: Thumb
node.description: The thick and short hand digit which is next to the index finger in humans.

node.name: Knuckles
node.description: A part of a finger at a joint where the bone is near the surface, especially where the finger joins the hand.

node.name: Palm
node.description: The part of the inner surface of the hand that extends from the wrist to the bases of the fingers.

node.name: Shoulder
node.description: Joint attaching upper arm to trunk.

node.name: Upper-arm
node.description: Portion of arm between shoulder and elbow.

node.name: Wrist
node.description: A joint between the distal end of the radius and the proximal row of carpal bones.

node.name: Organism
node.description: A living entity, more specifically a biological entity that consists of one or more cells and is capable of genomic replication (independently or not).

node.name: Animal
node.description: A living organism that has membranous cell walls, requires oxygen and organic foods, and is capable of voluntary movement.

node.name: Human
node.description: The bipedal primate mammal Homo sapiens.

node.name: Plant
node.description: Any living organism that typically synthesizes its food from inorganic substances and possesses cellulose cell walls.

node.name: Language-item
node.description: An entity related to a systematic means of communicating by the use of sounds, symbols, or gestures.

node.name: Character
node.description: A mark or symbol used in writing.

node.name: Clause
node.description: A unit of grammatical organization next below the sentence in rank, usually consisting of a subject and predicate.

node.name: Glyph
node.description: A hieroglyphic character, symbol, or pictograph.

node.name: Nonword
node.description: A group of letters or speech sounds that looks or sounds like a word but that is not accepted as such by native speakers.

node.name: Paragraph
node.description: A distinct section of a piece of writing, usually dealing with a single theme.

node.name: Phoneme
node.description: A speech sound that is distinguished by the speakers of a particular language.

node.name: Phrase
node.description: A phrase is a group of words functioning as a single unit in the syntax of a sentence.

node.name: Sentence
node.description: A set of words that is complete in itself, conveying a statement, question, exclamation, or command and typically containing an explicit or implied subject and a predicate containing a finite verb.

node.name: Syllable
node.description: A unit of spoken language larger than a phoneme.

node.name: Textblock
node.description: A block of text.

node.name: Word
node.description: A word is the smallest free form (an item that may be expressed in isolation with semantic or pragmatic content) in a language.

node.name: Object
node.description: Something perceptible by one or more of the senses, especially by vision or touch. A material thing.

node.name: Geometric-object
node.description: An object or a representation that has structure and topology in space.

node.name: 2D-shape
node.description: A planar, two-dimensional shape.

node.name: Arrow
node.description: A shape with a pointed end indicating direction.

node.name: Clockface
node.description: The dial face of a clock. A location identifier based on clockface numbering or anatomic subregion.

node.name: Cross
node.description: A figure or mark formed by two intersecting lines crossing at their midpoints.

node.name: Dash
node.description: A horizontal stroke in writing or printing to mark a pause or break in sense or to represent omitted letters or words.

node.name: Ellipse
node.description: A closed plane curve resulting from the intersection of a circular cone and a plane cutting completely through it, especially a plane not parallel to the base.

node.name: Circle
node.description: A ring-shaped structure with every point equidistant from the center.

node.name: Rectangle
node.description: A parallelogram with four right angles.

node.name: Square
node.description: A square is a special rectangle with four equal sides.

node.name: Single-point
node.description: A point is a geometric entity that is located in a zero-dimensional spatial region and whose position is defined by its coordinates in some coordinate system.

node.name: Star
node.description: A conventional or stylized representation of a star, typically one having five or more points.

node.name: Triangle
node.description: A three-sided polygon.

node.name: 3D-shape
node.description: A geometric three-dimensional shape.

node.name: Box
node.description: A square or rectangular vessel, usually made of cardboard or plastic.

node.name: Cube
node.description: A solid or semi-solid in the shape of a three dimensional square.

node.name: Cone
node.description: A shape whose base is a circle and whose sides taper up to a point.

node.name: Cylinder
node.description: A surface formed by circles of a given radius that are contained in a plane perpendicular to a given axis, whose centers align on the axis.

node.name: Ellipsoid
node.description: A closed plane curve resulting from the intersection of a circular cone and a plane cutting completely through it, especially a plane not parallel to the base.

node.name: Sphere
node.description: A solid or hollow three-dimensional object bounded by a closed surface such that every point on the surface is equidistant from the center.

node.name: Pyramid
node.description: A polyhedron of which one face is a polygon of any number of sides, and the other faces are triangles with a common vertex.

node.name: Pattern
node.description: An arrangement of objects, facts, behaviors, or other things which have scientific, mathematical, geometric, statistical, or other meaning.

node.name: Dots
node.description: A small round mark or spot.

node.name: LED-pattern
node.description: A pattern created by lighting selected members of a fixed light emitting diode array.

node.name: Ingestible-object
node.description: Something that can be taken into the body by the mouth for digestion or absorption.

node.name: Man-made-object
node.description: Something constructed by human means.

node.name: Building
node.description: A structure that has a roof and walls and stands more or less permanently in one place.

node.name: Attic
node.description: A room or a space immediately below the roof of a building.

node.name: Basement
node.description: The part of a building that is wholly or partly below ground level.

node.name: Entrance
node.description: The means or place of entry.

node.name: Roof
node.description: A roof is the covering on the uppermost part of a building which provides protection from animals and weather, notably rain, but also heat, wind and sunlight.

node.name: Room
node.description: An area within a building enclosed by walls and floor and ceiling.

node.name: Clothing
node.description: A covering designed to be worn on the body.

node.name: Device
node.description: An object contrived for a specific purpose.

node.name: Assistive-device
node.description: A device that help an individual accomplish a task.

node.name: Glasses
node.description: Frames with lenses worn in front of the eye for vision correction, eye protection, or protection from UV rays.

node.name: Writing-device
node.description: A device used for writing.

node.name: Pen
node.description: A common writing instrument used to apply ink to a surface for writing or drawing.

node.name: Pencil
node.description: An implement for writing or drawing that is constructed of a narrow solid pigment core in a protective casing that prevents the core from being broken or marking the hand.

node.name: Computing-device
node.description: An electronic device which take inputs and processes results from the inputs.

node.name: Cellphone
node.description: A telephone with access to a cellular radio system so it can be used over a wide area, without a physical connection to a network.

node.name: Desktop-computer
node.description: A computer suitable for use at an ordinary desk.

node.name: Laptop-computer
node.description: A computer that is portable and suitable for use while traveling.

node.name: Tablet-computer
node.description: A small portable computer that accepts input directly on to its screen rather than via a keyboard or mouse.

node.name: Engine
node.description: A motor is a machine designed to convert one or more forms of energy into mechanical energy.

node.name: IO-device
node.description: Hardware used by a human (or other system) to communicate with a computer.

node.name: Input-device
node.description: A piece of equipment used to provide data and control signals to an information processing system such as a computer or information appliance.

node.name: Computer-mouse
node.description: A hand-held pointing device that detects two-dimensional motion relative to a surface.

node.name: Mouse-button
node.description: An electric switch on a computer mouse which can be pressed or clicked to select or interact with an element of a graphical user interface.

node.name: Scroll-wheel
node.description: A scroll wheel or mouse wheel is a wheel used for scrolling made of hard plastic with a rubbery surface usually located between the left and right mouse buttons and is positioned perpendicular to the mouse surface.

node.name: Joystick
node.description: A control device that uses a movable handle to create two-axis input for a computer device.

node.name: Keyboard
node.description: A device consisting of mechanical keys that are pressed to create input to a computer.

node.name: Keyboard-key
node.description: A button on a keyboard usually representing letters, numbers, functions, or symbols.
Value of a keyboard key.

node.name: Keypad
node.description: A device consisting of keys, usually in a block arrangement, that provides limited input to a system.

node.name: Keypad-key
node.description: A key on a separate section of a computer keyboard that groups together numeric keys and those for mathematical or other special functions in an arrangement like that of a calculator.
Value of keypad key.

node.name: Microphone
node.description: A device designed to convert sound to an electrical signal.

node.name: Push-button
node.description: A switch designed to be operated by pressing a button.

node.name: Output-device
node.description: Any piece of computer hardware equipment which converts information into human understandable form.

node.name: Auditory-device
node.description: A device designed to produce sound.

node.name: Headphones
node.description: An instrument that consists of a pair of small loudspeakers, or less commonly a single speaker, held close to ears and connected to a signal source such as an audio amplifier, radio, CD player or portable media player.

node.name: Loudspeaker
node.description: A device designed to convert electrical signals to sounds that can be heard.

node.name: Display-device
node.description: An output device for presentation of information in visual or tactile form the latter used for example in tactile electronic displays for blind people.

node.name: Computer-screen
node.description: An electronic device designed as a display or a physical device designed to be a protective meshwork.

node.name: Screen-window
node.description: A part of a computer screen that contains a display different from the rest of the screen. A window is a graphical control element consisting of a visual area containing some of the graphical user interface of the program it belongs to and is framed by a window decoration.

node.name: Head-mounted-display
node.description: An instrument that functions as a display device, worn on the head or as part of a helmet, that has a small display optic in front of one (monocular HMD) or each eye (binocular HMD).

node.name: LED-display
node.description: A LED display is a flat panel display that uses an array of light-emitting diodes as pixels for a video display.

node.name: Recording-device
node.description: A device that copies information in a signal into a persistent information bearer.

node.name: EEG-recorder
node.description: A device for recording electric currents in the brain using electrodes applied to the scalp, to the surface of the brain, or placed within the substance of the brain.

node.name: File-storage
node.description: A device for recording digital information to a permanent media.

node.name: MEG-recorder
node.description: A device for measuring the magnetic fields produced by electrical activity in the brain, usually conducted externally.

node.name: Motion-capture
node.description: A device for recording the movement of objects or people.

node.name: Tape-recorder
node.description: A device for recording and reproduction usually using magnetic tape for storage that can be saved and played back.

node.name: Touchscreen
node.description: A control component that operates an electronic device by pressing the display on the screen.

node.name: Machine
node.description: A human-made device that uses power to apply forces and control movement to perform an action.

node.name: Measurement-device
node.description: A device in which a measure function inheres.

node.name: Clock
node.description: A device designed to indicate the time of day or to measure the time duration of an event or action.

node.name: Clock-face
node.description: A location identifier based on clockface numbering or anatomic subregion.

node.name: Robot
node.description: A mechanical device that sometimes resembles a living animal and is capable of performing a variety of often complex human tasks on command or by being programmed in advance.

node.name: Tool
node.description: A component that is not part of a device but is designed to support its assembly or operation.

node.name: Document
node.description: A physical object, or electronic counterpart, that is characterized by containing writing which is meant to be human-readable.

node.name: Book
node.description: A volume made up of pages fastened along one edge and enclosed between protective covers.

node.name: Letter
node.description: A written message addressed to a person or organization.

node.name: Note
node.description: A brief written record.

node.name: Notebook
node.description: A book for notes or memoranda.

node.name: Questionnaire
node.description: A document consisting of questions and possibly responses, depending on whether it has been filled out.

node.name: Furnishing
node.description: Furniture, fittings, and other decorative accessories, such as curtains and carpets, for a house or room.

node.name: Manufactured-material
node.description: Substances created or extracted from raw materials.

node.name: Ceramic
node.description: A hard, brittle, heat-resistant and corrosion-resistant material made by shaping and then firing a nonmetallic mineral, such as clay, at a high temperature.

node.name: Glass
node.description: A brittle transparent solid with irregular atomic structure.

node.name: Paper
node.description: A thin sheet material produced by mechanically or chemically processing cellulose fibres derived from wood, rags, grasses or other vegetable sources in water.

node.name: Plastic
node.description: Various high-molecular-weight thermoplastic or thermosetting polymers that are capable of being molded, extruded, drawn, or otherwise shaped and then hardened into a form.

node.name: Steel
node.description: An alloy made up of iron with typically a few tenths of a percent of carbon to improve its strength and fracture resistance compared to iron.

node.name: Media
node.description: Media are audo/visual/audiovisual modes of communicating information for mass consumption.

node.name: Media-clip
node.description: A short segment of media.

node.name: Audio-clip
node.description: A short segment of audio.

node.name: Audiovisual-clip
node.description: A short media segment containing both audio and video.

node.name: Video-clip
node.description: A short segment of video.

node.name: Visualization
node.description: An planned process that creates images, diagrams or animations from the input data.

node.name: Animation
node.description: A form of graphical illustration that changes with time to give a sense of motion or represent dynamic changes in the portrayal.

node.name: Art-installation
node.description: A large-scale, mixed-media constructions, often designed for a specific place or for a temporary period of time.

node.name: Braille
node.description: A display using a system of raised dots that can be read with the fingers by people who are blind.

node.name: Image
node.description: Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic.

node.name: Cartoon
node.description: A type of illustration, sometimes animated, typically in a non-realistic or semi-realistic style. The specific meaning has evolved over time, but the modern usage usually refers to either an image or series of images intended for satire, caricature, or humor. A motion picture that relies on a sequence of illustrations for its animation.

node.name: Drawing
node.description: A representation of an object or outlining a figure, plan, or sketch by means of lines.

node.name: Icon
node.description: A sign (such as a word or graphic symbol) whose form suggests its meaning.

node.name: Painting
node.description: A work produced through the art of painting.

node.name: Photograph
node.description: An image recorded by a camera.

node.name: Movie
node.description: A sequence of images displayed in succession giving the illusion of continuous movement.

node.name: Outline-visualization
node.description: A visualization consisting of a line or set of lines enclosing or indicating the shape of an object in a sketch or diagram.

node.name: Point-light-visualization
node.description: A display in which action is depicted using a few points of light, often generated from discrete sensors in motion capture.

node.name: Sculpture
node.description: A two- or three-dimensional representative or abstract forms, especially by carving stone or wood or by casting metal or plaster.

node.name: Stick-figure-visualization
node.description: A drawing showing the head of a human being or animal as a circle and all other parts as straight lines.

node.name: Navigational-object
node.description: An object whose purpose is to assist directed movement from one location to another.

node.name: Path
node.description: A trodden way. A way or track laid down for walking or made by continual treading.

node.name: Road
node.description: An open way for the passage of vehicles, persons, or animals on land.

node.name: Lane
node.description: A defined path with physical dimensions through which an object or substance may traverse.

node.name: Runway
node.description: A paved strip of ground on a landing field for the landing and takeoff of aircraft.

node.name: Vehicle
node.description: A mobile machine which transports people or cargo.

node.name: Aircraft
node.description: A vehicle which is able to travel through air in an atmosphere.

node.name: Bicycle
node.description: A human-powered, pedal-driven, single-track vehicle, having two wheels attached to a frame, one behind the other.

node.name: Boat
node.description: A watercraft of any size which is able to float or plane on water.

node.name: Car
node.description: A wheeled motor vehicle used primarily for the transportation of human passengers.

node.name: Cart
node.description: A cart is a vehicle which has two wheels and is designed to transport human passengers or cargo.

node.name: Tractor
node.description: A mobile machine specifically designed to deliver a high tractive effort at slow speeds, and mainly used for the purposes of hauling a trailer or machinery used in agriculture or construction.

node.name: Train
node.description: A connected line of railroad cars with or without a locomotive.

node.name: Truck
node.description: A motor vehicle which, as its primary function, transports cargo rather than human passangers.

node.name: Natural-object
node.description: Something that exists in or is produced by nature, and is not artificial or man-made.

node.name: Mineral
node.description: A solid, homogeneous, inorganic substance occurring in nature and having a definite chemical composition.

node.name: Natural-feature
node.description: A feature that occurs in nature. A prominent or identifiable aspect, region, or site of interest.

node.name: Field
node.description: An unbroken expanse as of ice or grassland.

node.name: Hill
node.description: A rounded elevation of limited extent rising above the surrounding land with local relief of less than 300m.

node.name: Mountain
node.description: A landform that extends above the surrounding terrain in a limited area.

node.name: River
node.description: A natural freshwater surface stream of considerable volume and a permanent or seasonal flow, moving in a definite channel toward a sea, lake, or another river.

node.name: Waterfall
node.description: A sudden descent of water over a step or ledge in the bed of a river.

node.name: Sound
node.description: Mechanical vibrations transmitted by an elastic medium. Something that can be heard.

node.name: Environmental-sound
node.description: Sounds occurring in the environment. An accumulation of noise pollution that occurs outside. This noise can be caused by transport, industrial, and recreational activities.

node.name: Crowd-sound
node.description: Noise produced by a mixture of sounds from a large group of people.

node.name: Signal-noise
node.description: Any part of a signal that is not the true or original signal but is introduced by the communication mechanism.

node.name: Musical-sound
node.description: Sound produced by continuous and regular vibrations, as opposed to noise.

node.name: Instrument-sound
node.description: Sound produced by a musical instrument.

node.name: Tone
node.description: A musical note, warble, or other sound used as a particular signal on a telephone or answering machine.

node.name: Vocalized-sound
node.description: Musical sound produced by vocal cords in a biological agent.

node.name: Named-animal-sound
node.description: A sound recognizable as being associated with particular animals.

node.name: Barking
node.description: Sharp explosive cries like sounds made by certain animals, especially a dog, fox, or seal.

node.name: Bleating
node.description: Wavering cries like sounds made by a sheep, goat, or calf.

node.name: Chirping
node.description: Short, sharp, high-pitched noises like sounds made by small birds or an insects.

node.name: Crowing
node.description: Loud shrill sounds characteristic of roosters.

node.name: Growling
node.description: Low guttural sounds like those that made in the throat by a hostile dog or other animal.

node.name: Meowing
node.description: Vocalizations like those made by as those cats. These sounds have diverse tones and are sometimes chattered, murmured or whispered. The purpose can be assertive.

node.name: Mooing
node.description: Deep vocal sounds like those made by a cow.

node.name: Purring
node.description: Low continuous vibratory sound such as those made by cats. The sound expresses contentment.

node.name: Roaring
node.description: Loud, deep, or harsh prolonged sounds such as those made by big cats and bears for long-distance communication and intimidation.

node.name: Squawking
node.description: Loud, harsh noises such as those made by geese.

node.name: Named-object-sound
node.description: A sound identifiable as coming from a particular type of object.

node.name: Alarm-sound
node.description: A loud signal often loud continuous ringing to alert people to a problem or condition that requires urgent attention.

node.name: Beep
node.description: A short, single tone, that is typically high-pitched and generally made by a computer or other machine.

node.name: Buzz
node.description: A persistent vibratory sound often made by a buzzer device and used to indicate something incorrect.

node.name: Click
node.description: The sound made by a mechanical cash register, often to designate a reward.

node.name: Ding
node.description: A short ringing sound such as that made by a bell, often to indicate a correct response or the expiration of time.

node.name: Horn-blow
node.description: A loud sound made by forcing air through a sound device that funnels air to create the sound, often used to sound an alert.

node.name: Ka-ching
node.description: The sound made by a mechanical cash register, often to designate a reward.

node.name: Siren
node.description: A loud, continuous sound often varying in frequency designed to indicate an emergency.

node.name: Physiologic-pattern
node.description: EEG graphoelements or rhythms that are considered normal. They only should be scored if the physician considers that they have a specific clinical significance for the recording.

node.name: Rhythmic-activity-pattern
node.description: Not further specified.

node.name: Slow-alpha-variant-rhythm
node.description: Characteristic rhythms mostly at 4-5 Hz, recorded most prominently over the posterior regions of the head. Generally alternate, or are intermixed, with alpha rhythm to which they often are harmonically related. Amplitude varies but is frequently close to 50 micro V. Blocked or attenuated by attention, especially visual, and mental effort. Comment: slow alpha variant rhythms should be distinguished from posterior slow waves characteristic of children and adolescents and occasionally seen in young adults.

node.name: Fast-alpha-variant-rhythm
node.description: Characteristic rhythm at 14-20 Hz, detected most prominently over the posterior regions of the head. May alternate or be intermixed with alpha rhythm. Blocked or attenuated by attention, especially visual, and mental effort.

node.name: Ciganek-rhythm
node.description: Midline theta rhythm (Ciganek rhythm) may be observed during wakefulness or drowsiness. The frequency is 4-7 Hz, and the location is midline (ie, vertex). The morphology is rhythmic, smooth, sinusoidal, arciform, spiky, or mu-like.

node.name: Lambda-wave
node.description: Diphasic sharp transient occurring over occipital regions of the head of waking subjects during visual exploration. The main component is positive relative to other areas. Time-locked to saccadic eye movement. Amplitude varies but is generally below 50 micro V.

node.name: Posterior-slow-waves-youth
node.description: Waves in the delta and theta range, of variable form, lasting 0.35 to 0.5 s or longer without any consistent periodicity, found in the range of 6-12 years (occasionally seen in young adults). Alpha waves are almost always intermingled or superimposed. Reactive similar to alpha activity.

node.name: Diffuse-slowing-hyperventilation
node.description: Diffuse slowing induced by hyperventilation. Bilateral, diffuse slowing during hyperventilation. Recorded in 70 percent of normal children (3-5 years) and less then 10 percent of adults. Usually appear in the posterior regions and spread forward in younger age group, whereas they tend to appear in the frontal regions and spread backward in the older age group.

node.name: Photic-driving
node.description: Physiologic response consisting of rhythmic activity elicited over the posterior regions of the head by repetitive photic stimulation at frequencies of about 5-30 Hz. Comments: term should be limited to activity time-locked to the stimulus and of frequency identical or harmonically related to the stimulus frequency. Photic driving should be distinguished from the visual evoked potentials elicited by isolated flashes of light or flashes repeated at very low frequency.

node.name: Photomyogenic-response
node.description: A response to intermittent photic stimulation characterized by the appearance in the record of brief, repetitive muscular artifacts (spikes) over the anterior regions of the head. These often increase gradually in amplitude as stimuli are continued and cease promptly when the stimulus is withdrawn. Comment: this response is frequently associated with flutter of the eyelids and vertical oscillations of the eyeballs and sometimes with discrete jerking mostly involving the musculature of the face and head. (Preferred to synonym: photo-myoclonic response).
Free text.

node.name: Polygraphic-channel-finding
node.description: Changes observed in polygraphic channels can be scored: EOG, Respiration, ECG, EMG, other polygraphic channel (+ free text), and their significance logged (normal, abnormal, no definite abnormality).

node.name: EOG-channel-finding
node.description: ElectroOculoGraphy.
