node.name: Property
node.description: Something that pertains to a thing. A characteristic of some entity. A quality or feature regarded as a characteristic or inherent part of someone or something. HED attributes are adjectives or adverbs.

node.name: Agent-property
node.description: Something that pertains to an agent.

node.name: Agent-state
node.description: The state of the agent.

node.name: Agent-cognitive-state
node.description: The state of the cognitive processes or state of mind of the agent.

node.name: Alert
node.description: Condition of heightened watchfulness or preparation for action.

node.name: Anesthetized
node.description: Having lost sensation to pain or having senses dulled due to the effects of an anesthetic.

node.name: Asleep
node.description: Having entered a periodic, readily reversible state of reduced awareness and metabolic activity, usually accompanied by physical relaxation and brain activity.

node.name: Attentive
node.description: Concentrating and focusing mental energy on the task or surroundings.

node.name: Awake
node.description: In a non sleeping state.

node.name: Brain-dead
node.description: Characterized by the irreversible absence of cortical and brain stem functioning.

node.name: Comatose
node.description: In a state of profound unconsciousness associated with markedly depressed cerebral activity.

node.name: Distracted
node.description: Lacking in concentration because of being preoccupied.

node.name: Drowsy
node.description: In a state of near-sleep, a strong desire for sleep, or sleeping for unusually long periods.

node.name: Intoxicated
node.description: In a state with disturbed psychophysiological functions and responses as a result of administration or ingestion of a psychoactive substance.

node.name: Locked-in
node.description: In a state of complete paralysis of all voluntary muscles except for the ones that control the movements of the eyes.

node.name: Passive
node.description: Not responding or initiating an action in response to a stimulus.

node.name: Resting
node.description: A state in which the agent is not exhibiting any physical exertion.

node.name: Vegetative
node.description: A state of wakefulness and conscience, but (in contrast to coma) with involuntary opening of the eyes and movements (such as teeth grinding, yawning, or thrashing of the extremities).

node.name: Agent-emotional-state
node.description: The status of the general temperament and outlook of an agent.

node.name: Angry
node.description: Experiencing emotions characterized by marked annoyance or hostility.

node.name: Aroused
node.description: In a state reactive to stimuli leading to increased heart rate and blood pressure, sensory alertness, mobility and readiness to respond.

node.name: Awed
node.description: Filled with wonder. Feeling grand, sublime or powerful emotions characterized by a combination of joy, fear, admiration, reverence, and/or respect.

node.name: Compassionate
node.description: Feeling or showing sympathy and concern for others often evoked for a person who is in distress and associated with altruistic motivation.

node.name: Content
node.description: Feeling satisfaction with things as they are.

node.name: Disgusted
node.description: Feeling revulsion or profound disapproval aroused by something unpleasant or offensive.

node.name: Emotionally-neutral
node.description: Feeling neither satisfied nor dissatisfied.

node.name: Empathetic
node.description: Understanding and sharing the feelings of another. Being aware of, being sensitive to, and vicariously experiencing the feelings, thoughts, and experience of another.

node.name: Excited
node.description: Feeling great enthusiasm and eagerness.

node.name: Fearful
node.description: Feeling apprehension that one may be in danger.

node.name: Frustrated
node.description: Feeling annoyed as a result of being blocked, thwarted, disappointed or defeated.

node.name: Grieving
node.description: Feeling sorrow in response to loss, whether physical or abstract.

node.name: Happy
node.description: Feeling pleased and content.

node.name: Jealous
node.description: Feeling threatened by a rival in a relationship with another individual, in particular an intimate partner, usually involves feelings of threat, fear, suspicion, distrust, anxiety, anger, betrayal, and rejection.

node.name: Joyful
node.description: Feeling delight or intense happiness.

node.name: Loving
node.description: Feeling a strong positive emotion of affection and attraction.

node.name: Relieved
node.description: No longer feeling pain, distress, anxiety, or reassured.

node.name: Sad
node.description: Feeling grief or unhappiness.

node.name: Stressed
node.description: Experiencing mental or emotional strain or tension.

node.name: Agent-physiological-state
node.description: Having to do with the mechanical, physical, or biochemical function of an agent.

node.name: Healthy
node.description: Having no significant health-related issues.

node.name: Hungry
node.description: Being in a state of craving or desiring food.

node.name: Rested
node.description: Feeling refreshed and relaxed.

node.name: Sated
node.description: Feeling full.

node.name: Sick
node.description: Being in a state of ill health, bodily malfunction, or discomfort.

node.name: Thirsty
node.description: Feeling a need to drink.

node.name: Tired
node.description: Feeling in need of sleep or rest.

node.name: Agent-postural-state
node.description: Pertaining to the position in which agent holds their body.

node.name: Crouching
node.description: Adopting a position where the knees are bent and the upper body is brought forward and down, sometimes to avoid detection or to defend oneself.

node.name: Eyes-closed
node.description: Keeping eyes closed with no blinking.

node.name: Eyes-open
node.description: Keeping eyes open with occasional blinking.

node.name: Kneeling
node.description: Positioned where one or both knees are on the ground.

node.name: On-treadmill
node.description: Ambulation on an exercise apparatus with an endless moving belt to support moving in place.

node.name: Prone
node.description: Positioned in a recumbent body position whereby the person lies on its stomach and faces downward.

node.name: Seated-with-chin-rest
node.description: Using a device that supports the chin and head.

node.name: Sitting
node.description: In a seated position.

node.name: Standing
node.description: Assuming or maintaining an erect upright position.

node.name: Agent-task-role
node.description: The function or part that is ascribed to an agent in performing the task.

node.name: Experiment-actor
node.description: An agent who plays a predetermined role to create the experiment scenario.

node.name: Experiment-controller
node.description: An agent exerting control over some aspect of the experiment.

node.name: Experiment-participant
node.description: Someone who takes part in an activity related to an experiment.

node.name: Experimenter
node.description: Person who is the owner of the experiment and has its responsibility.

node.name: Agent-trait
node.description: A genetically, environmentally, or socially determined characteristic of an agent.

node.name: Age
node.description: Length of time elapsed time since birth of the agent.

node.name: Agent-experience-level
node.description: Amount of skill or knowledge that the agent has as pertains to the task.

node.name: Expert-level
node.description: Having comprehensive and authoritative knowledge of or skill in a particular area related to the task.

node.name: Intermediate-experience-level
node.description: Having a moderate amount of knowledge or skill related to the task.

node.name: Novice-level
node.description: Being inexperienced in a field or situation related to the task.

node.name: Ethnicity
node.description: Belong to a social group that has a common national or cultural tradition. Use with Label to avoid extension.

node.name: Gender
node.description: Characteristics that are socially constructed, including norms, behaviors, and roles based on sex.

node.name: Handedness
node.description: Individual preference for use of a hand, known as the dominant hand.

node.name: Ambidextrous
node.description: Having no overall dominance in the use of right or left hand or foot in the performance of tasks that require one hand or foot.

node.name: Left-handed
node.description: Preference for using the left hand or foot for tasks requiring the use of a single hand or foot.

node.name: Right-handed
node.description: Preference for using the right hand or foot for tasks requiring the use of a single hand or foot.

node.name: Race
node.description: Belonging to a group sharing physical or social qualities as defined within a specified society. Use with Label to avoid extension.

node.name: Sex
node.description: Physical properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female.

node.name: Female
node.description: Biological sex of an individual with female sexual organs such ova.

node.name: Intersex
node.description: Having genitalia and/or secondary sexual characteristics of indeterminate sex.

node.name: Male
node.description: Biological sex of an individual with male sexual organs producing sperm.

node.name: Data-property
node.description: Something that pertains to data or information.

node.name: Data-marker
node.description: An indicator placed to mark something.

node.name: Data-break-marker
node.description: An indicator place to indicate a gap in the data.

node.name: Temporal-marker
node.description: An indicator placed at a particular time in the data.

node.name: Inset
node.description: Marks an intermediate point in an ongoing event of temporal extent.

node.name: Offset
node.description: Marks the end of an event of temporal extent.

node.name: Onset
node.description: Marks the start of an ongoing event of temporal extent.

node.name: Pause
node.description: Indicates the temporary interruption of the operation a process and subsequently wait for a signal to continue.

node.name: Time-out
node.description: A cancellation or cessation that automatically occurs when a predefined interval of time has passed without a certain event occurring.

node.name: Time-sync
node.description: A synchronization signal whose purpose to help synchronize different signals or processes. Often used to indicate a marker inserted into the recorded data to allow post hoc synchronization of concurrently recorded data streams.

node.name: Data-resolution
node.description: Smallest change in a quality being measured by an sensor that causes a perceptible change.

node.name: Printer-resolution
node.description: Resolution of a printer, usually expressed as the number of dots-per-inch for a printer.

node.name: Screen-resolution
node.description: Resolution of a screen, usually expressed as the of pixels in a dimension for a digital display device.

node.name: Sensory-resolution
node.description: Resolution of measurements by a sensing device.

node.name: Spatial-resolution
node.description: Linear spacing of a spatial measurement.

node.name: Spectral-resolution
node.description: Measures the ability of a sensor to resolve features in the electromagnetic spectrum.

node.name: Temporal-resolution
node.description: Measures the ability of a sensor to resolve features in time.

node.name: Data-source-type
node.description: The type of place, person, or thing from which the data comes or can be obtained.

node.name: Computed-feature
node.description: A feature computed from the data by a tool. This tag should be grouped with a label of the form Toolname_propertyName.

node.name: Computed-prediction
node.description: A computed extrapolation of known data.

node.name: Expert-annotation
node.description: An explanatory or critical comment or other in-context information provided by an authority.

node.name: Instrument-measurement
node.description: Information obtained from a device that is used to measure material properties or make other observations.

node.name: Observation
node.description: Active acquisition of information from a primary source. Should be grouped with a label of the form AgentID_featureName.

node.name: Data-value
node.description: Designation of the type of a data item.

node.name: Categorical-value
node.description: Indicates that something can take on a limited and usually fixed number of possible values.

node.name: Categorical-class-value
node.description: Categorical values that fall into discrete classes such as true or false. The grouping is absolute in the sense that it is the same for all participants.

node.name: All
node.description: To a complete degree or to the full or entire extent.

node.name: Correct
node.description: Free from error. Especially conforming to fact or truth.

node.name: Explicit
node.description: Stated clearly and in detail, leaving no room for confusion or doubt.

node.name: False
node.description: Not in accordance with facts, reality or definitive criteria.

node.name: Implicit
node.description: Implied though not plainly expressed.

node.name: Invalid
node.description: Not allowed or not conforming to the correct format or specifications.

node.name: None
node.description: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

node.name: Some
node.description: At least a small amount or number of, but not a large amount of, or often.

node.name: True
node.description: Conforming to facts, reality or definitive criteria.

node.name: Valid
node.description: Allowable, usable, or acceptable.

node.name: Wrong
node.description: Inaccurate or not correct.

node.name: Categorical-judgment-value
node.description: Categorical values that are based on the judgment or perception of the participant such familiar and famous.

node.name: Abnormal
node.description: Deviating in any way from the state, position, structure, condition, behavior, or rule which is considered a norm.

node.name: Asymmetrical
node.description: Lacking symmetry or having parts that fail to correspond to one another in shape, size, or arrangement.

node.name: Audible
node.description: A sound that can be perceived by the participant.

node.name: Complex
node.description: Hard, involved or complicated, elaborate, having many parts.

node.name: Congruent
node.description: Concordance of multiple evidence lines. In agreement or harmony.

node.name: Constrained
node.description: Keeping something within particular limits or bounds.

node.name: Disordered
node.description: Not neatly arranged. Confused and untidy. A structural quality in which the parts of an object are non-rigid.

node.name: Familiar
node.description: Recognized, familiar, or within the scope of knowledge.

node.name: Famous
node.description: A person who has a high degree of recognition by the general population for his or her success or accomplishments. A famous person.

node.name: Inaudible
node.description: A sound below the threshold of perception of the participant.

node.name: Incongruent
node.description: Not in agreement or harmony.

node.name: Involuntary
node.description: An action that is not made by choice. In the body, involuntary actions (such as blushing) occur automatically, and cannot be controlled by choice.

node.name: Masked
node.description: Information exists but is not provided or is partially obscured due to security, privacy, or other concerns.

node.name: Normal
node.description: Being approximately average or within certain limits. Conforming with or constituting a norm or standard or level or type or social norm.

node.name: Ordered
node.description: Conforming to a logical or comprehensible arrangement of separate elements.

node.name: Simple
node.description: Easily understood or presenting no difficulties.

node.name: Symmetrical
node.description: Made up of exactly similar parts facing each other or around an axis. Showing aspects of symmetry.

node.name: Unconstrained
node.description: Moving without restriction.

node.name: Unfamiliar
node.description: Not having knowledge or experience of.

node.name: Unmasked
node.description: Information is revealed.

node.name: Voluntary
node.description: Using free will or design; not forced or compelled; controlled by individual volition.

node.name: Categorical-level-value
node.description: Categorical values based on dividing a continuous variable into levels such as high and low.

node.name: Cold
node.description: Having an absence of heat.

node.name: Deep
node.description: Extending relatively far inward or downward.

node.name: High
node.description: Having a greater than normal degree, intensity, or amount.

node.name: Hot
node.description: Having an excess of heat.

node.name: Large
node.description: Having a great extent such as in physical dimensions, period of time, amplitude or frequency.

node.name: Liminal
node.description: Situated at a sensory threshold that is barely perceptible or capable of eliciting a response.

node.name: Loud
node.description: Having a perceived high intensity of sound.

node.name: Low
node.description: Less than normal in degree, intensity or amount.

node.name: Medium
node.description: Mid-way between small and large in number, quantity, magnitude or extent.

node.name: Negative
node.description: Involving disadvantage or harm.

node.name: Positive
node.description: Involving advantage or good.

node.name: Quiet
node.description: Characterizing a perceived low intensity of sound.

node.name: Rough
node.description: Having a surface with perceptible bumps, ridges, or irregularities.

node.name: Shallow
node.description: Having a depth which is relatively low.

node.name: Small
node.description: Having a small extent such as in physical dimensions, period of time, amplitude or frequency.

node.name: Smooth
node.description: Having a surface free from bumps, ridges, or irregularities.

node.name: Subliminal
node.description: Situated below a sensory threshold that is imperceptible or not capable of eliciting a response.

node.name: Supraliminal
node.description: Situated above a sensory threshold that is perceptible or capable of eliciting a response.

node.name: Thick
node.description: Wide in width, extent or cross-section.

node.name: Thin
node.description: Narrow in width, extent or cross-section.

node.name: Categorical-orientation-value
node.description: Value indicating the orientation or direction of something.

node.name: Backward
node.description: Directed behind or to the rear.

node.name: Downward
node.description: Moving or leading toward a lower place or level.

node.name: Forward
node.description: At or near or directed toward the front.

node.name: Horizontally-oriented
node.description: Oriented parallel to or in the plane of the horizon.

node.name: Leftward
node.description: Going toward or facing the left.

node.name: Oblique
node.description: Slanting or inclined in direction, course, or position that is neither parallel nor perpendicular nor right-angular.

node.name: Rightward
node.description: Going toward or situated on the right.

node.name: Rotated
node.description: Positioned offset around an axis or center.

node.name: Upward
node.description: Moving, pointing, or leading to a higher place, point, or level.

node.name: Vertically-oriented
node.description: Oriented perpendicular to the plane of the horizon.

node.name: Physical-value
node.description: The value of some physical property of something.

node.name: Temperature
node.description: A measure of hot or cold based on the average kinetic energy of the atoms or molecules in the system.

node.name: Weight
node.description: The relative mass or the quantity of matter contained by something.

node.name: Quantitative-value
node.description: Something capable of being estimated or expressed with numeric values.

node.name: Fraction
node.description: A numerical value between 0 and 1.

node.name: Item-count
node.description: The integer count of something which is usually grouped with the entity it is counting. (Item-count/3, A) indicates that 3 of A have occurred up to this point.

node.name: Item-index
node.description: The index of an item in a collection, sequence or other structure. (A (Item-index/3, B)) means that A is item number 3 in B.

node.name: Item-interval
node.description: An integer indicating how many items or entities have passed since the last one of these. An item interval of 0 indicates the current item.

node.name: Percentage
node.description: A fraction or ratio with 100 understood as the denominator.

node.name: Ratio
node.description: A quotient of quantities of the same kind for different components within the same system.

node.name: Spatiotemporal-value
node.description: A property relating to space and/or time.

node.name: Rate-of-change
node.description: The amount of change accumulated per unit time.

node.name: Acceleration
node.description: Magnitude of the rate of change in either speed or direction. The direction of change should be given separately.

node.name: Frequency
node.description: Frequency is the number of occurrences of a repeating event per unit time.

node.name: Jerk-rate
node.description: Magnitude of the rate at which the acceleration of an object changes with respect to time. The direction of change should be given separately.

node.name: Refresh-rate
node.description: The frequency with which the image on a computer monitor or similar electronic display screen is refreshed, usually expressed in hertz.

node.name: Sampling-rate
node.description: The number of digital samples taken or recorded per unit of time.

node.name: Speed
node.description: A scalar measure of the rate of movement of the object expressed either as the distance travelled divided by the time taken (average speed) or the rate of change of position with respect to time at a particular point (instantaneous speed). The direction of change should be given separately.

node.name: Temporal-rate
node.description: The number of items per unit of time.

node.name: Spatial-value
node.description: Value of an item involving space.

node.name: Angle
node.description: The amount of inclination of one line to another or the plane of one object to another.

node.name: Distance
node.description: A measure of the space separating two objects or points.

node.name: Position
node.description: A reference to the alignment of an object, a particular situation or view of a situation, or the location of an object. Coordinates with respect a specified frame of reference or the default Screen-frame if no frame is given.

node.name: X-position
node.description: The position along the x-axis of the frame of reference.

node.name: Y-position
node.description: The position along the y-axis of the frame of reference.

node.name: Z-position
node.description: The position along the z-axis of the frame of reference.

node.name: Size
node.description: The physical magnitude of something.

node.name: Area
node.description: The extent of a 2-dimensional surface enclosed within a boundary.

node.name: Depth
node.description: The distance from the surface of something especially from the perspective of looking from the front.

node.name: Height
node.description: The vertical measurement or distance from the base to the top of an object.

node.name: Length
node.description: The linear extent in space from one end of something to the other end, or the extent of something from beginning to end.

node.name: Volume
node.description: The amount of three dimensional space occupied by an object or the capacity of a space or container.

node.name: Width
node.description: The extent or measurement of something from side to side.

node.name: Temporal-value
node.description: A characteristic of or relating to time or limited by time.

node.name: Delay
node.description: The time at which an event start time is delayed from the current onset time. This tag defines the start time of an event of temporal extent and may be used with the Duration tag.

node.name: Duration
node.description: The period of time during which an event occurs. This tag defines the end time of an event of temporal extent and may be used with the Delay tag.

node.name: Time-interval
node.description: The period of time separating two instances, events, or occurrences.

node.name: Time-value
node.description: A value with units of time. Usually grouped with tags identifying what the value represents.

node.name: Statistical-value
node.description: A value based on or employing the principles of statistics.

node.name: Data-maximum
node.description: The largest possible quantity or degree.

node.name: Data-mean
node.description: The sum of a set of values divided by the number of values in the set.

node.name: Data-median
node.description: The value which has an equal number of values greater and less than it.

node.name: Data-minimum
node.description: The smallest possible quantity.

node.name: Probability
node.description: A measure of the expectation of the occurrence of a particular event.

node.name: Standard-deviation
node.description: A measure of the range of values in a set of numbers. Standard deviation is a statistic used as a measure of the dispersion or variation in a distribution, equal to the square root of the arithmetic mean of the squares of the deviations from the arithmetic mean.

node.name: Statistical-accuracy
node.description: A measure of closeness to true value expressed as a number between 0 and 1.

node.name: Statistical-precision
node.description: A quantitative representation of the degree of accuracy necessary for or associated with a particular action.

node.name: Statistical-recall
node.description: Sensitivity is a measurement datum qualifying a binary classification test and is computed by subtracting the false negative rate to the integral numeral 1.

node.name: Statistical-uncertainty
node.description: A measure of the inherent variability of repeated observation measurements of a quantity including quantities evaluated by statistical methods and by other means.

node.name: Data-variability-attribute
node.description: An attribute describing how something changes or varies.

node.name: Abrupt
node.description: Marked by sudden change.

node.name: Constant
node.description: Continually recurring or continuing without interruption. Not changing in time or space.

node.name: Continuous
node.description: Uninterrupted in time, sequence, substance, or extent.

node.name: Decreasing
node.description: Becoming smaller or fewer in size, amount, intensity, or degree.

node.name: Deterministic
node.description: No randomness is involved in the development of the future states of the element.

node.name: Discontinuous
node.description: Having a gap in time, sequence, substance, or extent.

node.name: Discrete
node.description: Constituting a separate entities or parts.

node.name: Estimated-value
node.description: Something that has been calculated or measured approximately.

node.name: Exact-value
node.description: A value that is viewed to the true value according to some standard.

node.name: Flickering
node.description: Moving irregularly or unsteadily or burning or shining fitfully or with a fluctuating light.

node.name: Fractal
node.description: Having extremely irregular curves or shapes for which any suitably chosen part is similar in shape to a given larger or smaller part when magnified or reduced to the same size.

node.name: Increasing
node.description: Becoming greater in size, amount, or degree.

node.name: Random
node.description: Governed by or depending on chance. Lacking any definite plan or order or purpose.

node.name: Repetitive
node.description: A recurring action that is often non-purposeful.

node.name: Stochastic
node.description: Uses a random probability distribution or pattern that may be analysed statistically but may not be predicted precisely to determine future states.

node.name: Varying
node.description: Differing in size, amount, degree, or nature.

node.name: Environmental-property
node.description: Relating to or arising from the surroundings of an agent.

node.name: Augmented-reality
node.description: Using technology that enhances real-world experiences with computer-derived digital overlays to change some aspects of perception of the natural environment. The digital content is shown to the user through a smart device or glasses and responds to changes in the environment.

node.name: Indoors
node.description: Located inside a building or enclosure.

node.name: Motion-platform
node.description: A mechanism that creates the feelings of being in a real motion environment.

node.name: Outdoors
node.description: Any area outside a building or shelter.

node.name: Real-world
node.description: Located in a place that exists in real space and time under realistic conditions.

node.name: Rural
node.description: Of or pertaining to the country as opposed to the city.

node.name: Terrain
node.description: Characterization of the physical features of a tract of land.

node.name: Composite-terrain
node.description: Tracts of land characterized by a mixture of physical features.

node.name: Dirt-terrain
node.description: Tracts of land characterized by a soil surface and lack of vegetation.

node.name: Grassy-terrain
node.description: Tracts of land covered by grass.

node.name: Gravel-terrain
node.description: Tracts of land covered by a surface consisting a loose aggregation of small water-worn or pounded stones.

node.name: Leaf-covered-terrain
node.description: Tracts of land covered by leaves and composited organic material.

node.name: Muddy-terrain
node.description: Tracts of land covered by a liquid or semi-liquid mixture of water and some combination of soil, silt, and clay.

node.name: Paved-terrain
node.description: Tracts of land covered with concrete, asphalt, stones, or bricks.

node.name: Rocky-terrain
node.description: Tracts of land consisting or full of rock or rocks.

node.name: Sloped-terrain
node.description: Tracts of land arranged in a sloping or inclined position.

node.name: Uneven-terrain
node.description: Tracts of land that are not level, smooth, or regular.

node.name: Urban
node.description: Relating to, located in, or characteristic of a city or densely populated area.

node.name: Virtual-world
node.description: Using technology that creates immersive, computer-generated experiences that a person can interact with and navigate through. The digital content is generally delivered to the user through some type of headset and responds to changes in head position or through interaction with other types of sensors. Existing in a virtual setting such as a simulation or game environment.

node.name: Informational-property
node.description: Something that pertains to a task.

node.name: Description
node.description: An explanation of what the tag group it is in means. If the description is at the top-level of an event string, the description applies to the event.

node.name: ID
node.description: An alphanumeric name that identifies either a unique object or a unique class of objects. Here the object or class may be an idea, physical countable object (or class), or physical uncountable substance (or class).

node.name: Label
node.description: A string of 20 or fewer characters identifying something. Labels usually refer to general classes of things while IDs refer to specific instances. A term that is associated with some entity. A brief description given for purposes of identification. An identifying or descriptive marker that is attached to an object.

node.name: Metadata
node.description: Data about data. Information that describes another set of data.

node.name: CogAtlas
node.description: The Cognitive Atlas ID number of something.

node.name: CogPo
node.description: The CogPO ID number of something.

node.name: Creation-date
node.description: The date on which data creation of this element began.

node.name: Experimental-note
node.description: A brief written record about the experiment.

node.name: Library-name
node.description: Official name of a HED library.

node.name: OBO-identifier
node.description: The identifier of a term in some Open Biology Ontology (OBO) ontology.

node.name: Pathname
node.description: The specification of a node (file or directory) in a hierarchical file system, usually specified by listing the nodes top-down.

node.name: Subject-identifier
node.description: A sequence of characters used to identify, name, or characterize a trial or study subject.

node.name: Version-identifier
node.description: An alphanumeric character string that identifies a form or variant of a type or original.
Usually is a semantic version.

node.name: Parameter
node.description: Something user-defined for this experiment.

node.name: Parameter-label
node.description: The name of the parameter.

node.name: Parameter-value
node.description: The value of the parameter.

node.name: Organizational-property
node.description: Relating to an organization or the action of organizing something.

node.name: Collection
node.description: A tag designating a grouping of items such as in a set or list.
Name of the collection.

node.name: Condition-variable
node.description: An aspect of the experiment or task that is to be varied during the experiment. Task-conditions are sometimes called independent variables or contrasts.
Name of the condition variable.

node.name: Control-variable
node.description: An aspect of the experiment that is fixed throughout the study and usually is explicitly controlled.
Name of the control variable.

node.name: Def
node.description: A HED-specific utility tag used with a defined name to represent the tags associated with that definition.
Name of the definition.

node.name: Def-expand
node.description: A HED specific utility tag that is grouped with an expanded definition. The child value of the Def-expand is the name of the expanded definition.

node.name: Definition
node.description: A HED-specific utility tag whose child value is the name of the concept and the tag group associated with the tag is an English language explanation of a concept.
Name of the definition.

node.name: Event-context
node.description: A special HED tag inserted as part of a top-level tag group to contain information about the interrelated conditions under which the event occurs. The event context includes information about other events that are ongoing when this event happens.

node.name: Event-stream
node.description: A special HED tag indicating that this event is a member of an ordered succession of events.
Name of the event stream.

node.name: Experimental-intertrial
node.description: A tag used to indicate a part of the experiment between trials usually where nothing is happening.
Optional label for the intertrial block.

node.name: Experimental-trial
node.description: Designates a run or execution of an activity, for example, one execution of a script. A tag used to indicate a particular organizational part in the experimental design often containing a stimulus-response pair or stimulus-response-feedback triad.
Optional label for the trial (often a numerical string).

node.name: Indicator-variable
node.description: An aspect of the experiment or task that is measured as task conditions are varied during the experiment. Experiment indicators are sometimes called dependent variables.
Name of the indicator variable.

node.name: Recording
node.description: A tag designating the data recording. Recording tags are usually have temporal scope which is the entire recording.
Optional label for the recording.

node.name: Task
node.description: An assigned piece of work, usually with a time allotment. A tag used to indicate a linkage the structured activities performed as part of the experiment.
Optional label for the task block.

node.name: Time-block
node.description: A tag used to indicate a contiguous time block in the experiment during which something is fixed or noted.
Optional label for the task block.

node.name: Sensory-property
node.description: Relating to sensation or the physical senses.

node.name: Sensory-attribute
node.description: A sensory characteristic associated with another entity.

node.name: Auditory-attribute
node.description: Pertaining to the sense of hearing.

node.name: Loudness
node.description: Perceived intensity of a sound.

node.name: Pitch
node.description: A perceptual property that allows the user to order sounds on a frequency scale.

node.name: Sound-envelope
node.description: Description of how a sound changes over time.

node.name: Sound-envelope-attack
node.description: The time taken for initial run-up of level from nil to peak usually beginning when the key on a musical instrument is pressed.

node.name: Sound-envelope-decay
node.description: The time taken for the subsequent run down from the attack level to the designated sustain level.

node.name: Sound-envelope-release
node.description: The time taken for the level to decay from the sustain level to zero after the key is released.

node.name: Sound-envelope-sustain
node.description: The time taken for the main sequence of the sound duration, until the key is released.

node.name: Sound-volume
node.description: The sound pressure level (SPL) usually the ratio to a reference signal estimated as the lower bound of hearing.

node.name: Timbre
node.description: The perceived sound quality of a singing voice or musical instrument.

node.name: Gustatory-attribute
node.description: Pertaining to the sense of taste.

node.name: Bitter
node.description: Having a sharp, pungent taste.

node.name: Salty
node.description: Tasting of or like salt.

node.name: Savory
node.description: Belonging to a taste that is salty or spicy rather than sweet.

node.name: Sour
node.description: Having a sharp, acidic taste.

node.name: Sweet
node.description: Having or resembling the taste of sugar.

node.name: Olfactory-attribute
node.description: Having a smell.

node.name: Somatic-attribute
node.description: Pertaining to the feelings in the body or of the nervous system.

node.name: Pain
node.description: The sensation of discomfort, distress, or agony, resulting from the stimulation of specialized nerve endings.

node.name: Stress
node.description: The negative mental, emotional, and physical reactions that occur when environmental stressors are perceived as exceeding the adaptive capacities of the individual.

node.name: Tactile-attribute
node.description: Pertaining to the sense of touch.

node.name: Tactile-pressure
node.description: Having a feeling of heaviness.

node.name: Tactile-temperature
node.description: Having a feeling of hotness or coldness.

node.name: Tactile-texture
node.description: Having a feeling of roughness.

node.name: Tactile-vibration
node.description: Having a feeling of mechanical oscillation.

node.name: Vestibular-attribute
node.description: Pertaining to the sense of balance or body position.

node.name: Visual-attribute
node.description: Pertaining to the sense of sight.

node.name: Color
node.description: The appearance of objects (or light sources) described in terms of perception of their hue and lightness (or brightness) and saturation.

node.name: CSS-color
node.description: One of 140 colors supported by all browsers. For more details such as the color RGB or HEX values, check: https://www.w3schools.com/colors/colors_groups.asp.

node.name: Color-shade
node.description: A slight degree of difference between colors, especially with regard to how light or dark it is or as distinguished from one nearly like it.

node.name: Dark-shade
node.description: A color tone not reflecting much light.

node.name: Light-shade
node.description: A color tone reflecting more light.

node.name: Grayscale
node.description: Using a color map composed of shades of gray, varying from black at the weakest intensity to white at the strongest.
White intensity between 0 and 1.

node.name: HSV-color
node.description: A color representation that models how colors appear under light.

node.name: HSV-value
node.description: An attribute of a visual sensation according to which an area appears to emit more or less light.

node.name: Hue
node.description: Attribute of a visual sensation according to which an area appears to be similar to one of the perceived colors.
Angular value between 0 and 360.

node.name: Saturation
node.description: Colorfulness of a stimulus relative to its own brightness.
B value of RGB between 0 and 1.

node.name: RGB-color
node.description: A color from the RGB schema.

node.name: RGB-blue
node.description: The blue component.
B value of RGB between 0 and 1.

node.name: RGB-green
node.description: The green component.
G value of RGB between 0 and 1.

node.name: RGB-red
node.description: The red component.
R value of RGB between 0 and 1.

node.name: Luminance
node.description: A quality that exists by virtue of the luminous intensity per unit area projected in a given direction.

node.name: Opacity
node.description: A measure of impenetrability to light.

node.name: Sensory-presentation
node.description: The entity has a sensory manifestation.

node.name: Auditory-presentation
node.description: The sense of hearing is used in the presentation to the user.

node.name: Loudspeaker-separation
node.description: The distance between two loudspeakers. Grouped with the Distance tag.

node.name: Monophonic
node.description: Relating to sound transmission, recording, or reproduction involving a single transmission path.

node.name: Silent
node.description: The absence of ambient audible sound or the state of having ceased to produce sounds.

node.name: Stereophonic
node.description: Relating to, or constituting sound reproduction involving the use of separated microphones and two transmission channels to achieve the sound separation of a live hearing.

node.name: Gustatory-presentation
node.description: The sense of taste used in the presentation to the user.

node.name: Olfactory-presentation
node.description: The sense of smell used in the presentation to the user.

node.name: Somatic-presentation
node.description: The nervous system is used in the presentation to the user.

node.name: Tactile-presentation
node.description: The sense of touch used in the presentation to the user.

node.name: Vestibular-presentation
node.description: The sense balance used in the presentation to the user.

node.name: Visual-presentation
node.description: The sense of sight used in the presentation to the user.

node.name: 2D-view
node.description: A view showing only two dimensions.

node.name: 3D-view
node.description: A view showing three dimensions.

node.name: Background-view
node.description: Parts of the view that are farthest from the viewer and usually the not part of the visual focus.

node.name: Bistable-view
node.description: Something having two stable visual forms that have two distinguishable stable forms as in optical illusions.

node.name: Foreground-view
node.description: Parts of the view that are closest to the viewer and usually the most important part of the visual focus.

node.name: Foveal-view
node.description: Visual presentation directly on the fovea. A view projected on the small depression in the retina containing only cones and where vision is most acute.

node.name: Map-view
node.description: A diagrammatic representation of an area of land or sea showing physical features, cities, roads.

node.name: Aerial-view
node.description: Elevated view of an object from above, with a perspective as though the observer were a bird.

node.name: Satellite-view
node.description: A representation as captured by technology such as a satellite.

node.name: Street-view
node.description: A 360-degrees panoramic view from a position on the ground.

node.name: Peripheral-view
node.description: Indirect vision as it occurs outside the point of fixation.

node.name: Task-property
node.description: Something that pertains to a task.

node.name: Task-action-type
node.description: How an agent action should be interpreted in terms of the task specification.

node.name: Appropriate-action
node.description: An action suitable or proper in the circumstances.

node.name: Correct-action
node.description: An action that was a correct response in the context of the task.

node.name: Correction
node.description: An action offering an improvement to replace a mistake or error.

node.name: Done-indication
node.description: An action that indicates that the participant has completed this step in the task.

node.name: Imagined-action
node.description: Form a mental image or concept of something. This is used to identity something that only happened in the imagination of the participant as in imagined movements in motor imagery paradigms.

node.name: Inappropriate-action
node.description: An action not in keeping with what is correct or proper for the task.

node.name: Incorrect-action
node.description: An action considered wrong or incorrect in the context of the task.

node.name: Indeterminate-action
node.description: An action that cannot be distinguished between two or more possibibities in the current context. This tag might be applied when an outside evaluator or a classification algorithm cannot determine a definitive result.

node.name: Miss
node.description: An action considered to be a failure in the context of the task. For example, if the agent is supposed to try to hit a target and misses.

node.name: Near-miss
node.description: An action barely satisfied the requirements of the task. In a driving experiment for example this could pertain to a narrowly avoided collision or other accident.

node.name: Omitted-action
node.description: An expected response was skipped.

node.name: Ready-indication
node.description: An action that indicates that the participant is ready to perform the next step in the task.

node.name: Task-attentional-demand
node.description: Strategy for allocating attention toward goal-relevant information.

node.name: Bottom-up-attention
node.description: Attentional guidance purely by externally driven factors to stimuli that are salient because of their inherent properties relative to the background. Sometimes this is referred to as stimulus driven.

node.name: Covert-attention
node.description: Paying attention without moving the eyes.

node.name: Divided-attention
node.description: Integrating parallel multiple stimuli. Behavior involving responding simultaneously to multiple tasks or multiple task demands.

node.name: Focused-attention
node.description: Responding discretely to specific visual, auditory, or tactile stimuli.

node.name: Orienting-attention
node.description: Directing attention to a target stimulus.

node.name: Overt-attention
node.description: Selectively processing one location over others by moving the eyes to point at that location.

node.name: Selective-attention
node.description: Maintaining a behavioral or cognitive set in the face of distracting or competing stimuli. Ability to pay attention to a limited array of all available sensory information.

node.name: Sustained-attention
node.description: Maintaining a consistent behavioral response during continuous and repetitive activity.

node.name: Switched-attention
node.description: Having to switch attention between two or more modalities of presentation.

node.name: Top-down-attention
node.description: Voluntary allocation of attention to certain features. Sometimes this is referred to goal-oriented attention.

node.name: Task-effect-evidence
node.description: The evidence supporting the conclusion that the event had the specified effect.

node.name: Behavioral-evidence
node.description: An indication or conclusion based on the behavior of an agent.

node.name: Computational-evidence
node.description: A type of evidence in which data are produced, and/or generated, and/or analyzed on a computer.

node.name: External-evidence
node.description: A phenomenon that follows and is caused by some previous phenomenon.

node.name: Intended-effect
node.description: A phenomenon that is intended to follow and be caused by some previous phenomenon.

node.name: Task-event-role
node.description: The purpose of an event with respect to the task.

node.name: Experimental-stimulus
node.description: Part of something designed to elicit a response in the experiment.

node.name: Incidental
node.description: A sensory or other type of event that is unrelated to the task or experiment.

node.name: Instructional
node.description: Usually associated with a sensory event intended to give instructions to the participant about the task or behavior.

node.name: Mishap
node.description: Unplanned disruption such as an equipment or experiment control abnormality or experimenter error.

node.name: Participant-response
node.description: Something related to a participant actions in performing the task.

node.name: Task-activity
node.description: Something that is part of the overall task or is necessary to the overall experiment but is not directly part of a stimulus-response cycle. Examples would be taking a survey or provided providing a silva sample.

node.name: Warning
node.description: Something that should warn the participant that the parameters of the task have been or are about to be exceeded such as a warning message about getting too close to the shoulder of the road in a driving task.

node.name: Task-relationship
node.description: Specifying organizational importance of sub-tasks.

node.name: Background-subtask
node.description: A part of the task which should be performed in the background as for example inhibiting blinks due to instruction while performing the primary task.

node.name: Primary-subtask
node.description: A part of the task which should be the primary focus of the participant.

node.name: Task-stimulus-role
node.description: The role the stimulus plays in the task.

node.name: Cue
node.description: A signal for an action, a pattern of stimuli indicating a particular response.

node.name: Distractor
node.description: A person or thing that distracts or a plausible but incorrect option in a multiple-choice question. In pyschological studies this is sometimes referred to as a foil.

node.name: Expected
node.description: Considered likely, probable or anticipated. Something of low information value as in frequent non-targets in an RSVP paradigm.

node.name: Extraneous
node.description: Irrelevant or unrelated to the subject being dealt with.

node.name: Feedback
node.description: An evaluative response to an inquiry, process, event, or activity.

node.name: Go-signal
node.description: An indicator to proceed with a planned action.

node.name: Meaningful
node.description: Conveying significant or relevant information.

node.name: Newly-learned
node.description: Representing recently acquired information or understanding.

node.name: Non-informative
node.description: Something that is not useful in forming an opinion or judging an outcome.

node.name: Non-target
node.description: Something other than that done or looked for. Also tag Expected if the Non-target is frequent.

node.name: Not-meaningful
node.description: Not having a serious, important, or useful quality or purpose.

node.name: Novel
node.description: Having no previous example or precedent or parallel.

node.name: Oddball
node.description: Something unusual, or infrequent.

node.name: Penalty
node.description: A disadvantage, loss, or hardship due to some action.

node.name: Planned
node.description: Something that was decided on or arranged in advance.

node.name: Priming
node.description: An implicit memory effect in which exposure to a stimulus influences response to a later stimulus.

node.name: Query
node.description: A sentence of inquiry that asks for a reply.

node.name: Reward
node.description: A positive reinforcement for a desired action, behavior or response.

node.name: Stop-signal
node.description: An indicator that the agent should stop the current activity.

node.name: Target
node.description: Something fixed as a goal, destination, or point of examination.

node.name: Threat
node.description: An indicator that signifies hostility and predicts an increased probability of attack.

node.name: Timed
node.description: Something planned or scheduled to be done at a particular time or lasting for a specified amount of time.

node.name: Unexpected
node.description: Something that is not anticipated.

node.name: Unplanned
node.description: Something that has not been planned as part of the task.

node.name: Relation
node.description: Concerns the way in which two or more people or things are connected.

node.name: Comparative-relation
node.description: Something considered in comparison to something else. The first entity is the focus.

node.name: Approximately-equal-to
node.description: (A, (Approximately-equal-to, B)) indicates that A and B have almost the same value. Here A and B could refer to sizes, orders, positions or other quantities.

node.name: Equal-to
node.description: (A, (Equal-to, B)) indicates that the size or order of A is the same as that of B.

node.name: Greater-than
node.description: (A, (Greater-than, B)) indicates that the relative size or order of A is bigger than that of B.

node.name: Greater-than-or-equal-to
node.description: (A, (Greater-than-or-equal-to, B)) indicates that the relative size or order of A is bigger than or the same as that of B.

node.name: Less-than
node.description: (A, (Less-than, B)) indicates that A is smaller than B. Here A and B could refer to sizes, orders, positions or other quantities.

node.name: Less-than-or-equal-to
node.description: (A, (Less-than-or-equal-to, B)) indicates that the relative size or order of A is smaller than or equal to B.

node.name: Not-equal-to
node.description: (A, (Not-equal-to, B)) indicates that the size or order of A is not the same as that of B.

node.name: Connective-relation
node.description: Indicates two entities are related in some way. The first entity is the focus.

node.name: Belongs-to
node.description: (A, (Belongs-to, B)) indicates that A is a member of B.

node.name: Connected-to
node.description: (A, (Connected-to, B)) indicates that A is related to B in some respect, usually through a direct link.

node.name: Contained-in
node.description: (A, (Contained-in, B)) indicates that A is completely inside of B.

node.name: Described-by
node.description: (A, (Described-by, B)) indicates that B provides information about A.

node.name: From-to
node.description: (A, (From-to, B)) indicates a directional relation from A to B. A is considered the source.

node.name: Group-of
node.description: (A, (Group-of, B)) indicates A is a group of items of type B.

node.name: Implied-by
node.description: (A, (Implied-by, B)) indicates B is suggested by A.

node.name: Includes
node.description: (A, (Includes, B)) indicates that A has B as a member or part.

node.name: Interacts-with
node.description: (A, (Interacts-with, B)) indicates A and B interact, possibly reciprocally.

node.name: Member-of
node.description: (A, (Member-of, B)) indicates A is a member of group B.

node.name: Part-of
node.description: (A, (Part-of, B)) indicates A is a part of the whole B.

node.name: Performed-by
node.description: (A, (Performed-by, B)) indicates that the action or procedure A was carried out by agent B.

node.name: Performed-using
node.description: (A, (Performed-using, B)) indicates that the action or procedure A was accomplished using B.

node.name: Related-to
node.description: (A, (Related-to, B)) indicates A has some relationship to B.

node.name: Unrelated-to
node.description: (A, (Unrelated-to, B)) indicates that A is not related to B. For example, A is not related to Task.

node.name: Directional-relation
node.description: A relationship indicating direction of change of one entity relative to another. The first entity is the focus.

node.name: Away-from
node.description: (A, (Away-from, B)) indicates that A is going or has moved away from B. The meaning depends on A and B.

node.name: Towards
node.description: (A, (Towards, B)) indicates that A is going to or has moved to B. The meaning depends on A and B.

node.name: Logical-relation
node.description: Indicating a logical relationship between entities. The first entity is usually the focus.

node.name: And
node.description: (A, (And, B)) means A and B are both in effect.

node.name: Or
node.description: (A, (Or, B)) means at least one of A and B are in effect.

node.name: Spatial-relation
node.description: Indicating a relationship about position between entities.

node.name: Above
node.description: (A, (Above, B)) means A is in a place or position that is higher than B.

node.name: Across-from
node.description: (A, (Across-from, B)) means A is on the opposite side of something from B.

node.name: Adjacent-to
node.description: (A, (Adjacent-to, B)) indicates that A is next to B in time or space.

node.name: Ahead-of
node.description: (A, (Ahead-of, B)) indicates that A is further forward in time or space in B.

node.name: Around
node.description: (A, (Around, B)) means A is in or near the present place or situation of B.

node.name: Behind
node.description: (A, (Behind, B)) means A is at or to the far side of B, typically so as to be hidden by it.

node.name: Below
node.description: (A, (Below, B)) means A is in a place or position that is lower than the position of B.

node.name: Between
node.description: (A, (Between, (B, C))) means A is in the space or interval separating B and C.

node.name: Bilateral-to
node.description: (A, (Bilateral, B)) means A is on both sides of B or affects both sides of B.

node.name: Bottom-edge-of
node.description: (A, (Bottom-edge-of, B)) means A is on the bottom most part or or near the boundary of B.

node.name: Boundary-of
node.description: (A, (Boundary-of, B)) means A is on or part of the edge or boundary of B.

node.name: Center-of
node.description: (A, (Center-of, B)) means A is at a point or or in an area that is approximately central within B.

node.name: Close-to
node.description: (A, (Close-to, B)) means A is at a small distance from or is located near in space to B.

node.name: Far-from
node.description: (A, (Far-from, B)) means A is at a large distance from or is not located near in space to B.

node.name: In-front-of
node.description: (A, (In-front-of, B)) means A is in a position just ahead or at the front part of B, potentially partially blocking B from view.

node.name: Left-edge-of
node.description: (A, (Left-edge-of, B)) means A is located on the left side of B on or near the boundary of B.

node.name: Left-side-of
node.description: (A, (Left-side-of, B)) means A is located on the left side of B usually as part of B.

node.name: Lower-center-of
node.description: (A, (Lower-center-of, B)) means A is situated on the lower center part of B (due south). This relation is often used to specify qualitative information about screen position.

node.name: Lower-left-of
node.description: (A, (Lower-left-of, B)) means A is situated on the lower left part of B. This relation is often used to specify qualitative information about screen position.

node.name: Lower-right-of
node.description: (A, (Lower-right-of, B)) means A is situated on the lower right part of B. This relation is often used to specify qualitative information about screen position.

node.name: Outside-of
node.description: (A, (Outside-of, B)) means A is located in the space around but not including B.

node.name: Over
node.description: (A, (Over, B)) means A above is above B so as to cover or protect or A extends over the a general area as from a from a vantage point.

node.name: Right-edge-of
node.description: (A, (Right-edge-of, B)) means A is located on the right side of B on or near the boundary of B.

node.name: Right-side-of
node.description: (A, (Right-side-of, B)) means A is located on the right side of B usually as part of B.

node.name: To-left-of
node.description: (A, (To-left-of, B)) means A is located on or directed toward the side to the west of B when B is facing north. This term is used when A is not part of B.

node.name: To-right-of
node.description: (A, (To-right-of, B)) means A is located on or directed toward the side to the east of B when B is facing north. This term is used when A is not part of B.

node.name: Top-edge-of
node.description: (A, (Top-edge-of, B)) means A is on the uppermost part or or near the boundary of B.

node.name: Top-of
node.description: (A, (Top-of, B)) means A is on the uppermost part, side, or surface of B.

node.name: Underneath
node.description: (A, (Underneath, B)) means A is situated directly below and may be concealed by B.

node.name: Upper-center-of
node.description: (A, (Upper-center-of, B)) means A is situated on the upper center part of B (due north). This relation is often used to specify qualitative information about screen position.

node.name: Upper-left-of
node.description: (A, (Upper-left-of, B)) means A is situated on the upper left part of B. This relation is often used to specify qualitative information about screen position.

node.name: Upper-right-of
node.description: (A, (Upper-right-of, B)) means A is situated on the upper right part of B. This relation is often used to specify qualitative information about screen position.

node.name: Within
node.description: (A, (Within, B)) means A is on the inside of or contained in B.

node.name: Temporal-relation
node.description: A relationship that includes a temporal or time-based component.

node.name: After
node.description: (A, (After B)) means A happens at a time subsequent to a reference time related to B.

node.name: Asynchronous-with
node.description: (A, (Asynchronous-with, B)) means A happens at times not occurring at the same time or having the same period or phase as B.

node.name: Before
node.description: (A, (Before B)) means A happens at a time earlier in time or order than B.

node.name: During
node.description: (A, (During, B)) means A happens at some point in a given period of time in which B is ongoing.

node.name: Synchronous-with
node.description: (A, (Synchronous-with, B)) means A happens at occurs at the same time or rate as B.

node.name: Waiting-for
node.description: (A, (Waiting-for, B)) means A pauses for something to happen in B.

node.name: Sleep-and-drowsiness
node.description: The features of the ongoing activity during sleep are scored here. If abnormal graphoelements appear, disappear or change their morphology during sleep, that is not scored here but at the entry corresponding to that graphooelement (as a modulator).

node.name: Sleep-architecture
node.description: For longer recordings. Only to be scored if whole-night sleep is part of the recording. It is a global descriptor of the structure and pattern of sleep: estimation of the amount of time spent in REM and NREM sleep, sleep duration, NREM-REM cycle.

node.name: Sleep-stage-reached
node.description: For normal sleep patterns the sleep stages reached during the recording can be specified

node.name: Sleep-stage-N1
node.description: Sleep stage 1.
Free text.

node.name: Sleep-stage-N2
node.description: Sleep stage 2.
Free text.

node.name: Sleep-stage-N3
node.description: Sleep stage 3.
Free text.

node.name: Sleep-stage-REM
node.description: Rapid eye movement.
Free text.

node.name: Sleep-spindles
node.description: Burst at 11-15 Hz but mostly at 12-14 Hz generally diffuse but of higher voltage over the central regions of the head, occurring during sleep. Amplitude varies but is mostly below 50 microV in the adult.

node.name: Arousal-pattern
node.description: Arousal pattern in children. Prolonged, marked high voltage 4-6/s activity in all leads with some intermixed slower frequencies, in children.

node.name: Frontal-arousal-rhythm
node.description: Prolonged (up to 20s) rhythmical sharp or spiky activity over the frontal areas (maximum over the frontal midline) seen at arousal from sleep in children with minimal cerebral dysfunction.

node.name: Vertex-wave
node.description: Sharp potential, maximal at the vertex, negative relative to other areas, apparently occurring spontaneously during sleep or in response to a sensory stimulus during sleep or wakefulness. May be single or repetitive. Amplitude varies but rarely exceeds 250 microV. Abbreviation: V wave. Synonym: vertex sharp wave.

node.name: K-complex
node.description: A burst of somewhat variable appearance, consisting most commonly of a high voltage negative slow wave followed by a smaller positive slow wave frequently associated with a sleep spindle. Duration greater than 0.5 s. Amplitude is generally maximal in the frontal vertex. K complexes occur during nonREM sleep, apparently spontaneously, or in response to sudden sensory / auditory stimuli, and are not specific for any individual sensory modality.

node.name: Saw-tooth-waves
node.description: Vertex negative 2-5 Hz waves occurring in series during REM sleep

node.name: POSTS
node.description: Positive occipital sharp transients of sleep. Sharp transient maximal over the occipital regions, positive relative to other areas, apparently occurring spontaneously during sleep. May be single or repetitive. Amplitude varies but is generally below 50 microV.

node.name: Hypnagogic-hypersynchrony
node.description: Bursts of bilateral, synchronous delta or theta activity of large amplitude, occasionally with superimposed faster components, occurring during falling asleep or during awakening, in children.

node.name: Non-reactive-sleep
node.description: EEG activity consisting of normal sleep graphoelements, but which cannot be interrupted by external stimuli/ the patient cannot be waken.

node.name: Uncertain-significant-pattern
node.description: EEG graphoelements or rhythms that resemble abnormal patterns but that are not necessarily associated with a pathology, and the physician does not consider them abnormal in the context of the scored recording (like normal variants and patterns).

node.name: Wicket-spikes
node.description: Spike-like monophasic negative single waves or trains of waves occurring over the temporal regions during drowsiness that have an arcuate or mu-like appearance. These are mainly seen in older individuals and represent a benign variant that is of little clinical significance.

node.name: Small-sharp-spikes
node.description: Benign epileptiform Transients of Sleep (BETS). Small sharp spikes (SSS) of very short duration and low amplitude, often followed by a small theta wave, occurring in the temporal regions during drowsiness and light sleep. They occur on one or both sides (often asynchronously). The main negative and positive components are of about equally spiky character. Rarely seen in children, they are seen most often in adults and the elderly. Two thirds of the patients have a history of epileptic seizures.

node.name: Fourteen-six-Hz-positive-burst
node.description: Burst of arch-shaped waves at 13-17 Hz and/or 5-7-Hz but most commonly at 14 and or 6 Hz seen generally over the posterior temporal and adjacent areas of one or both sides of the head during sleep. The sharp peaks of its component waves are positive with respect to other regions. Amplitude varies but is generally below 75 micro V. Comments: (1) best demonstrated by referential recording using contralateral earlobe or other remote, reference electrodes. (2) This pattern has no established clinical significance.

node.name: Six-Hz-spike-slow-wave
node.description: Spike and slow wave complexes at 4-7Hz, but mostly at 6 Hz occurring generally in brief bursts bilaterally and synchronously, symmetrically or asymmetrically, and either confined to or of larger amplitude over the posterior or anterior regions of the head. The spike has a strong positive component. Amplitude varies but is generally smaller than that of spike-and slow-wave complexes repeating at slower rates. Comment: this pattern should be distinguished from epileptiform discharges. Synonym: wave and spike phantom.

node.name: Rudimentary-spike-wave-complex
node.description: Synonym: Pseudo petit mal discharge. Paroxysmal discharge that consists of generalized or nearly generalized high voltage 3 to 4/sec waves with poorly developed spike in the positive through between the slow waves, occurring in drowsiness only. It is found only in infancy and early childhood when marked hypnagogic rhythmical theta activity is paramount in the drowsy state.

node.name: Slow-fused-transient
node.description: A posterior slow-wave preceded by a sharp-contoured potential that blends together with the ensuing slow wave, in children.

node.name: Needle-like-occipital-spikes-blind
node.description: Spike discharges of a particularly fast and needle-like character develop over the occipital region in most congenitally blind children. Completely disappear during childhood or adolescence.

node.name: Subclinical-rhythmic-EEG-discharge-adults
node.description: Subclinical rhythmic EEG discharge of adults (SERDA). A rhythmic pattern seen in the adult age group, mainly in the waking state or drowsiness. It consists of a mixture of frequencies, often predominant in the theta range. The onset may be fairly abrupt with widespread sharp rhythmical theta and occasionally with delta activity. As to the spatial distribution, a maximum of this discharge is usually found over the centroparietal region and especially over the vertex. It may resemble a seizure discharge but is not accompanied by any clinical signs or symptoms.

node.name: Rhythmic-temporal-theta-burst-drowsiness
node.description: Rhythmic temporal theta burst of drowsiness (RTTD). Characteristic burst of 4-7 Hz waves frequently notched by faster waves, occurring over the temporal regions of the head during drowsiness. Synonym: psychomotor variant pattern. Comment: this is a pattern of drowsiness that is of no clinical significance.

node.name: Temporal-slowing-elderly
node.description: Focal theta and/or delta activity over the temporal regions, especially the left, in persons over the age of 60. Amplitudes are low/similar to the background activity. Comment: focal temporal theta was found in 20 percent of people between the ages of 40-59 years, and 40 percent of people between 60 and 79 years. One third of people older than 60 years had focal temporal delta activity.

node.name: Breach-rhythm
node.description: Rhythmical activity recorded over cranial bone defects. Usually it is in the 6 to 11/sec range, does not respond to movements.
Free text.

unitClassDefinition.name: currencyUnits
unitClassDefinition.description: Units indicating the worth of something.

unit.name: dB
unit.description: Intensity expressed as ratio to a threshold. May be used for sound intensity.

unit.name: candela
unit.description: Units used to express light intensity.

unit.name: cd
unit.description: Units used to express light intensity.

unitClassDefinition.name: magneticFieldUnits
unitClassDefinition.description: Units used to magnetic field intensity.

valueClassDefinition.name: dateTimeClass
valueClassDefinition.description: Date-times should conform to ISO8601 date-time format YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss. Any variation on the full form is allowed.

valueClassDefinition.name: nameClass
valueClassDefinition.description: Value class designating values that have the characteristics of node names. The allowed characters are alphanumeric, hyphen, and underbar.

valueClassDefinition.name: numericClass
valueClassDefinition.description: Value must be a valid numerical value.

valueClassDefinition.name: textClass
valueClassDefinition.description: Value class designating values that have the characteristics of text such as in descriptions.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: allowedCharacter
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute of value classes specifying a special character that is allowed in expressing the value of a placeholder. Normally the allowed characters are listed individually. However, the word letters designates the upper and lower case alphabetic characters and the word digits designates the digits 0-9. The word blank designates the blank character.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: conversionFactor
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: The multiplicative factor to multiply these units to convert to default units.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: deprecatedFrom
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: Indicates that this element is deprecated. The value of the attribute is the latest schema version in which the element appeared in undeprecated form.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: defaultUnits
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute of unit classes specifying the default units to use if the placeholder has a unit class but the substituted value has no units.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: extensionAllowed
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute indicating that users can add unlimited levels of child nodes under this tag. This tag is propagated to child nodes with the exception of the hashtag placeholders.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: inLibrary
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: Indicates this schema element came from the named library schema, not the standard schema. This attribute is added by tools when a library schema is merged into its partnered standard schema.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: recommended
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute indicating that the event-level HED string should include this tag.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: relatedTag
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute suggesting HED tags that are closely related to this tag. This attribute is used by tagging tools.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: requireChild
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute indicating that one of the node elements descendants must be included when using this tag.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: required
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute indicating that every event-level HED string should include this tag.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: reserved
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute indicating that this tag has special meaning and requires special handling by tools.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: rooted
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: Indicates a top-level library schema node is identical to a node of the same name in the partnered standard schema. This attribute can only appear in nodes that have the inLibrary schema attribute.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: SIUnit
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute indicating that this unit element is an SI unit and can be modified by multiple and submultiple names. Note that some units such as byte are designated as SI units although they are not part of the standard.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: SIUnitModifier
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute indicating that this SI unit modifier represents a multiple or submultiple of a base unit rather than a unit symbol.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: SIUnitSymbolModifier
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute indicating that this SI unit modifier represents a multiple or submultiple of a unit symbol rather than a base symbol.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: suggestedTag
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute that indicates another tag that is often associated with this tag. This attribute is used by tagging tools to provide tagging suggestions.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: tagGroup
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute indicating the tag can only appear inside a tag group.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: takesValue
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute indicating the tag is a hashtag placeholder that is expected to be replaced with a user-defined value.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: topLevelTagGroup
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute indicating that this tag (or its descendants) can only appear in a top-level tag group. A tag group can have at most one tag with this attribute.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: unique
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute indicating that only one of this tag or its descendants can be used in the event-level HED string.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: unitClass
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute specifying which unit class this value tag belongs to.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: unitPrefix
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute applied specifically to unit elements to designate that the unit indicator is a prefix (e.g., dollar sign in the currency units).

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: unitSymbol
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute indicating this tag is an abbreviation or symbol representing a type of unit. Unit symbols represent both the singular and the plural and thus cannot be pluralized.

schemaAttributeDefinition.name: valueClass
schemaAttributeDefinition.description: A schema attribute specifying which value class this value tag belongs to.

propertyDefinition.name: boolProperty
propertyDefinition.description: Indicates that the schema attribute represents something that is either true or false and does not have a value. Attributes without this value are assumed to have string values.

propertyDefinition.name: elementProperty
propertyDefinition.description: Indicates this schema attribute can apply to any type of element(tag term, unit class, etc).

propertyDefinition.name: isInheritedProperty
propertyDefinition.description: Indicates that this attribute is inherited by child nodes. This property only applies to schema attributes for nodes.

propertyDefinition.name: nodeProperty
propertyDefinition.description: Indicates this schema attribute applies to node (tag-term) elements. This was added to allow for an attribute to apply to multiple elements.

propertyDefinition.name: unitClassProperty
propertyDefinition.description: Indicates that the schema attribute is meant to be applied to unit classes.

propertyDefinition.name: unitModifierProperty
propertyDefinition.description: Indicates that the schema attribute is meant to be applied to unit modifier classes.

propertyDefinition.name: unitProperty
propertyDefinition.description: Indicates that the schema attribute is meant to be applied to units within a unit class.

propertyDefinition.name: valueClassProperty
propertyDefinition.description: Indicates that the schema attribute is meant to be applied to value classes.

HED.epilogue:
The Standardized Computer-based Organized Reporting of EEG (SCORE) is a standard terminology for scalp EEG data assessment designed for use in clinical practice that may also be used for research purposes. The SCORE standard defines terms for describing phenomena observed in scalp EEG data. It is also potentially applicable (with some suitable extensions) to EEG recorded in critical care and neonatal settings. The SCORE standard received European consensus and has been endorsed by the European Chapter of the International Federation of Clinical Neurophysiology (IFCN) and the International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) Commission on European Affairs. A second revised and extended version of SCORE achieved international consensus.
[1] Beniczky, Sandor, et al. "Standardized computer based organized reporting of EEG: SCORE." Epilepsia 54.6 (2013). [2] Beniczky, Sandor, et al. "Standardized computer based organized reporting of EEG: SCORE second version." Clinical Neurophysiology 128.11 (2017).
TPA, March 2023
